title: wolf of wall street wannabe
story: Jordan Homer, , totalled his flash motor just four months after buying it when he flipped over on the M near Winchester, Hants.But the trader later quipped to his , Instagram followers that at least his pricey Gucci slider flip flops had survived the crash.Jordan, from Southampton, said: “It was a second hand car worth £,, but it will be a write-off.“Surprisingly I’ve only got a small cut on my body - I probably put my hand on a bit of glass as obviously the car was upside down.He added: “A lot of people have noticed my Gucci slider which was in my boot and it slapped my face as we were flipping around and landed on my lap.“You’ve got to look at the bright side of these thingsI get upset about everything then it’s going to be an issue and people are going to be like ‘oh you’re crying’, so I thought I’d remain positive.”Jordan lost control when his car aquaplaned - something police say was caused by his use of incorrect tyres.Hampshire Constabulary said the tyres didn’t meet the minimum required tread depth and this was why his BMW flipped.Jordan claims to earn a six figure salary Forex trading and his Instagram is littered with photos of him posing with Dom Perignon champagne and Rolexes in front of iconic landmarks and idyllic beach views.Other photos show him gloating over wads of cash and parading round his Louis Vuitton shopping bags.However, followers on social media have accused him of being irresponsible and said he should have splashed his cash on safer tyres instead of designer gear.One follower called him a “donut” and advised him to invest his high salary in some driving lessons, while another branded him as a “Wolf of Wall Street wannabe” - but one that “couldn’t afford tyres for his car”.Jordan disputes that his tread depth was illegal and explained that he was out and about during lockdown to pick up a bike for exercise – not flouting social distancing rules.Jordan said: “It’s frustrating as [its been made out online to] make me seem like the young person disobeying the laws going out when social distancing - it was a completely necessary trip.“I did everything correctly and it was just unfortunate that I was in the wrong place at the wrong time.”Hants Road Policing blamed the tyres for the accident and said the vehicle lost control due to lack of grip and aquaplaned.They tweeted: Please check the inside as well as outside tread of your tyres. Especiallyyou have high power rear wheel drive car with wide wheels.This one was under the legal tread depth which will explain why its now upside down. No injuries this time thankfully.Hampshire Constabulary said Jordan’s tyres did not meet the minimum required tread depth - but he claims they were well over the limit and that he is pursuing overturning the three points on his licence with police.Jordan said: “The police said there was nobody at fault it was just one of those things - aquaplaning happens.“The tires are absolutely fine - the police measured the rest of the treads and they were all about mm worth of tread depth - which is .mm over the legal requirements.A spokesman for Hampshire Constabulary said: “We were called just before .pm to a report of a vehicle overturned on the hard shoulder of the M southbound between junctions  and  near Winchester.No injuries were reported. The driver was reported for having tyres which did not meet the minimum required tread depth.”

title: dramatic moment man tasered chain

Im here and I dont give a f**k.As one officer continues to try and calm him down, he points at the others and says: Ill find out your name...Ill find out your name...Im coming for all you motherf***ers.I promise you, Im from Bradford me. title: elon musks children baby grimes
story: Its the -year-old singers first child and Musks seventh.On May , , Elon Musk and his partner Grimes announced the arrival of their little boy.When Musks followers pressed him for a name, he joked that the newborn is called X Æ A- Musk.The name appeared to be partially inspired by one of the songs from -year-old Grimes last album - ÆM.The Tesla CEO, , posted a cute snap of their sleeping baby using a face tattoo filter, as well as one of him cradling the newborn at the hospital.Responding to a fan who said their son is gorgeous, Musk joked about the tattoos: Thanks : Never too young for some ink haha.Grimes announced she was pregnant in January, and Musk had previously said the baby was expected to arrive Monday, May .Mom  baby all good, Musk wrote in a short Twitter post on Monday, May .South African tech mogul Musk has six sons from his previous marriage.All of the boys were born while he was married to his first we, Justine Wilson.The pair separated in  after eight years.Their first child, Nevada Alexander Musk, died of sudden infant death syndromeat the age of  weeks.The couple later had five sons through IVF – twins Grfin and Xavier, who were born in , followed by triplets Kai, Saxon and Damian in .Little is known about the boys.However, it is known that the couple share custody.And in a previous interview, Ms Wilson said: Almost all of my non-work waking hours are spent with my boys, and they are the love of my le.”Musk has never spoken publicly about his le with his sons.After he and his first we orced, Musk married English actress Talulah Riley in  and remarried her in  after the pair briefly orced in .The pair finally orced for the second time in October .Actress Amber Heard, who is orced from Johnny Depp, was in an on-off relationship with Musk.Musk is in a relationship with Grimes, , aka Claire Boucher, with whom he now has one son.The couple made their debut at the Met Gala in May .Elon Musk was born in Pretoria, South Africa in .As a -year-old child he taught himself computer programming and sold the code of a video game to a PC magazine for  .At , he moved to Canada to study, before gaining two degrees in physics and business at the University of Pennsylvania.At the age of  he moved to Calornia to start a Ph.D. in applied physics and material science at Stanford University - but left the programme after just two days to pursue other projects.Now , he is the founder and CEO of SpaceX, co-founder, CEO and product architect of Tesla Motors, co-founder and chairman of SolarCity, co-chairman of Opan AI, co-founder of Zip and founder of X, which merged with PayPal.His stated aim is to reduce global warming and save humans from extinction by setting up a colony on Mars.The billionaire inventor is also working on the worlds largest lithium-ion battery to store renewable energy.In addition to his primary business pursuits, Musk has envisioned a high-speed transportation system known as the Hyperloop, and has proposed a vertical take-off and landing supersonic jet electric aircraft with electric fan propulsion, known as the Musk electric jet.In , he faced a defamation case brought by hero Brit er Vernon Unsworth.Musk had branded Unsworth a child rapist in an explosive email after the cave expert helped rescue a trapped Thai youth football team in .He was cleared of defamation.

title: uk traffic light system lockdown sage
story: BRITAIN could have a traffic-light system in place to ease the countrywide lockdown, scientic documents revealed today.Data from the Governments Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies released today showed that any measures should be released gradually.And as The Sun revealed last month, a red, yellow and green system is on the cards and could form the basis of a fresh public health campaign.The SAGE documents said: Methods that have been used successfully for helping people understand how to implement other behaviour changesinclude providing a ‘traffic light’ list of examples of high , mediumand lowrisk activities and ‘modelling’ stories describing how other people like themselves in similar situations have overcome barriers to implement guidance successfully.It said that extending public heath campaigns with in-depth guidance and support could gradually help Brits to exit the lockdown.The green phase could include things like going for exercise, going back to school, to the shops, and to work.Amber might be seeing friends or family - but only in small groups and infrequently.And red would be things that are still shut down or not advised - such as large group activities, going to pubs and bars, or flocking to crowded spaces.However, it was not specic on which measures we might see - and when.The traffic light system would help Brits see easily what measures they can do freely, and which ones they should take more caution in.Ministers have repeatedly said measures would only be lted gradually, and others may take weeks or even months to change.The traffic light system is currently used in food messaging to put Brits off buying fatty ready meals and encourage them to buy healthy ones with a green logo on instead.Boris Johnson is due to set out his roadmap out of the lockdown later this week.He will show the nation his plans for opening up schools, workplaces and giving the economy a much-needed boost.Scientic documents released earlier today also revealed:But radical measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus in workplaces will be in place for up to a year, The Sun has been told.Screens between desks, staff sitting back-to-back and a ban on hot desking and sharing of equipment are among moves employers must introduce when lockdown is lted.The new measures — proposed in draft documents on ato workplaces — also require staggered sht times to avoid crowding on public transport.Handwashing kits must be at entry and exit points, with regular cleaning of worktops. Yellow and black tape will tell people where to stand in lts.One-way systems will be the norm in offices and on train s and at bus stops.Face-to-face meetings will only be able to go aheadabsolutely necessary and be time-limited.Employees will even be told not to share stationary such as pens.The message to employers is to allow their staff to work from homethey’re not needed in the workplace.It means home-working will likely become the default for millions of Brits for the foreseeable future.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. their homes just once a day for exercise and also for essential journeys, such as key workers getting to work or trips to the supermarket.Police have been given extra powers to fine people who breach the lockdown rules, which have been put in place to help stop the spread of coronavirus.The queue for the drive-through in Glasgow near the Braehead Shopping Centre was said to stretch as far back to the main road near the M in Hillington.In Edinburgh, drivers queued around the car park as they waited to be served by the baristas, who were wearing protective gloves and masks.In the Scottish capital, two Costas were open, the Sharpdale and South Bridge branches.Some customers reported waiting for hours for their favourite brew during the coronavirus lockdown.Long queues were also spotted title: social distance hats china
story: Inspired by schoolchildren seen wearing similar headgear last week, Shiniuzhai National Geological Park in Pingjiang County, in Central China’s Hunan Province, endorsed the use of the wacky headgear.The creative caps - made mostly using long balloons or plastic - are being offered to fee-paying tourists who come through its gates.Images released on Saturdayshow visitors now not only wearing face masks, but also the -foot-wide caps in order to remind themselves and others to practice social distancing in order to stop the spread of the coronavirus.Shiniuzhai park said visitors queueing at the entrance awaiting temperature screening and ticket checks were handed the one-metre hats for free.It was piloted at the start of the Labour Day holidays to great success and popularity, the park reported.The park is known for its sweeping canyon views as well as a transparent clfside walkway made entirely out of toughened glass and metal.It is also home to China’s first-ever glass-bottom bridge, Haohan Qiao , which originally consisted of wooden planks before it was converted in .In accordance with central government guidelines, the national park said it was regularly disinfecting crowded areas and improving visitor flow.Tourists on its glass bridge and walkway have also been encouraged not to linger or gather in large numbers.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: aer lingus no social distancing flight
story: The flight from Belfast to London Heathrow had “no social distancing whatsoever”, despite the strict government guidelines.Flyer Sean Mallon told BBC Radio Ulster: “I would say there was about  per cent of the seats taken on the flight”.Aer Lingus has vowed to launch a probe into the scenes after the pictures of the packed flight were shared on social media.The airline said any process changes required would be implemented as a matter of urgency.In a statement, the airline said: In light of the unexpectedly high loads on the Belfast-London Heathrow service this morning and the level of demand for the route, Aer Lingus is reviewing its processes and procedures applicable to the operation of this service.The safety and security of Aer Linguss customers and crew is our top priority and any process changes that are identied as being required will be implemented as a matter of urgency.It comes after transport secretary Grant Shapps warned that foreign travellers to the UK could be forced to enter into a -day coronavirus quarantine.He told the BBC’s Andrew Marr show that as infections rate in Britain decrease it was crucial that “we do ensure that the sacrices...that were asking the British people to make are matched by anyone who comes to this country.However, industry bosses believe such a move would effectively kill air travel.Today it was revealed that around million people were let into Britain without any screening as covid- spread across the world.Shocking figures from the Home Office reveal just  travellers from virus ground zero Wuhan and Tokyo were forced to self-isolate after entering the UK.They came in on four flights from China and Japan in January and February as the virus spread across the world and were taken to specialist facilities in Milton Keynes and Merseyside.But between January and March  - when lockdown came into force - more than million entered Britain without screening for the deadly disease.Although the figures include arrivals from all destinations, the Home Office believes tens of thousands of these would come from countries ravaged by the disease.Since the killer bugs first victim on March , at least , people have died from the virus and , have been infected.Labour MP and member of the Home Affairs Select Committee, Stephen Doughty, said the startling figures beggar belief.He told the : The fact that many of these people then likely arrived and travelled onwards across the UK with little or no adherence to social distancing, and with no checks or protections at the border – barely a whf of hand sanitiser – is deeply disturbing.“Let alone the arrival of , fans from Madrid as the pandemic picked up speed.“Yet arrivals continue to this day – with no formal quarantine requirements. It is simply staggering.”

title: when golf courses reopen uk lockdown
story: GOLF courses all over the UK have been closed during the coronavirus lockdown, along with most other sports.As the nation waits with baited breath for the latest on lockdown restrictions, will golf courses be allowed to reopen There has been no set date as to when golf courses will be open to the public again.Despite this, there have been hints by the Culture Secretary, Oliver Dowden, that golf may be one of the sports resumed again before a host of others.He said that his department is gathering evidence on which sports can be played while respecting social distancing safely, and that golf was one of these sports being discussed.There has been a growing number of calls for golf clubs to be opened up again to its members.Former Scottish councillor, David May, has said the reasoning behind closing most institutions to combat Covid- does not apply to golf because distancing comes naturally to the sport.He has been one of the people most vocal about clubs re-opening and has joined a petition on Change.org, along with , others, asking the UK government to allow golfers to play again.The petitions founder Daniel Palmer, told THECOURIER: This is no dferent from walking in a park or field, I risk my le everyday still going to work and going to the supermarket once a week, but I am not allowed to walk and play a round of golf in the open air, this doesn’t make sense under the current exercise allowance.”Although there has been no official dates given for golfs , there has been a few whispers from well-known golf sources that aof the sport is imminent.The BBC’s  golf title: furlough scheme wind down chancellor lockdown
story: RISHI Sunak has begun detailed planning on how to wind down the Governments subsidised furlough scheme without causing a clf edge.One of the options being considered by the Chancellor is cutting the wage subsidy down to  per cent - as much as £ a month - to encourage people to look for new jobs.The scheme could then be reduced even further over coming months, according to the Evening Standard.Another option being looked at is to allow some furloughed staff to work, but with a smaller subsidy from the public purse.It would follow a similar plan devised by French President Emmanuel Macron, which helps shops and other businesses that cannot operate at full capacity because of social distancing measures and do not need staff full-time.It comes as: So far . million people have been furloughed because of the economic shutdown caused by coronavirus - at a staggering cost of £billion.Furloughed workers currently have  per cent of their wage subsidised up to £, a month.The scheme will continue until the end of June.Overall,  million people are being funded by the state - more than half of all adult Brits.But the Chancellor has said he aims to wind down the scheme gradually over the next few months.He has been clear there will be no clf edge, which MPs fear would trigger mass redundancies.The Treasury is expected to make crucial calls on the subsidy scheme this week, ahead of Boris Johnsons announcement on Sunday to lay out a blueprint to ease restrictions.A Government source said: “We are going to see a winding-down of the scheme and people being eased back to work gently.“What that will look like is the subject of discussions this week and the details are still being looked at by the Treasury.Mr Sunak told ITV the Government would end up spending as much on furloughed employees as it does on the NHSthere were no changes.He said: Clearly that is not a sustainable situation which is why, as soon as the time is right, we want to get people back to work and the economy fired up again.However the government does not envisage making signicant payouts to public sector employees as they believe most will continue offering essential services.Where employers are receiving public funding for staff costs, they will be expected to continue using these funds to pay staff rather than applying for the furlough scheme.If you are working at reduced hours and pay, you will not be eligible for furlough and it will be up to your employer to pay you as normal.You must have created and started a PAYE payroll scheme on or before March ,  and have a UK bank account.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer agreed the scheme could not go on infinitely and urged the Chancellor to create a category of semi-furloughed people who can work part time, and to grant an extension to businesses which could stay closed for months - such as pubs and restaurants.The cost of the scheme was nearly twice as high as the estimates from last month, with , employers putting their staff on furlough.Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said: “It’s a good scheme. But at the end of the day we have got to get our economy back up and running and we’ve got to try and encourage as many people back to the workplace.”Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: “We obviously need to get people safely back to work so we can withdraw from that scheme.It’s been very successful at keeping jobs and firms alive ... we also need to wean people off it.”British Airways announced they would be making , people redundant, despite putting , of its , employees on furlough - triggering redundancy fears within the Government. Another option - to end furloughing sector by sector as more areas of the economy are released - was rejected over concerns of creating a clf-edge for some workers but not others.A spokesman for No said: You heard from the Chancellor last night where he said he was working on the most effective way to wind down the scheme and ease people back into work.Ultimately we do need to make sure we can get our economy fired up and people get back to work.Treasury sources did not comment on the specics of the scheme.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: extreme nature tv host stung asian giant hornet
story: Nathaniel Coyote Peterson, the host of the YouTube show Brave Wilderness, dedicated one of his shows to feel the painful sting of Japans most notorious insect firsthand.The November  episode showed Peterson capturing the huge hornet in Japans Tottori Prefecture - what he calls one of the remote stretches of wilderness in the country - and ultimately placing it on his left forearm.Once he placed the monstrous insect on his arm with tweezers, he shouted in pain just seconds later.He said: “Oh man, wave of dizziness really quick. Oh, searing pain! Absolute searing pain!Almost immediately after the sting, a large welt appeared on his arm.Cant touch near it! Sharp shooting painI touch near it, he exclaimed.The -year-old YouTuber - who also hosts Animal Planet’s Coyote Peterson: Brave the Wild - told the New York Post Monday that the killer insect is the king of thing that formulates nightmares.“In Japan, they actually call them the great sparrow bee because when they’re flying, they look like a bird.According to Peterson the scary hornets have a -inch wing span and sound like an apache helicopter.You can definitely hear them before you see them.The killer insects can sting multiple times and deliver seven times the amount of venom as a honey bee - the equivalent to that of a venomous snack.In the video, when Peterson first captured the insect above plants, he said: My hand is shaking.“Look at that beast. Everything about this creature screams, ‘Run in the other direction.’Due to the possibility of the sting causing a le-threatening allergic reaction, Peterson had an EpiPen readily available just in case.In Petersons opinion, the sting is rated a  - on a scale of -.He explained: “But no matter how you break it down, this sting is incredibly dangerous.“If you were to be swarmed by  or  bees and be stung repetitively, yes, there is a good chance you will die.Two of the killer hornets were first spotted in the US in Blaine, Washington, in December .Thankfully, scientists are quickly looking to wipe out giant Murder Hornets that have found their way into North America.Researchers at the Washington State Department of Agricultureare trying to stop Asian Giant Hornets from nesting and breeding in Canada and Washington.Native to the forests and low mountains of Southeast Asia and Japan, Asian Giant Hornets have been dubbed the Murder Hornet because its known to kill people.Multiple stings can kill humans - eventheyre not allergic, according to WSU.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kim jong un double north korea
story: State-run media released images and video apparently showing the -year-old at a fertiliser factory  - amid escalating reports he was either dead or fighting for his le.Now eagle-eyed web sleuths believe it was really a lookalike on the photos and they point to changes in his face, hair and teeth compared to previous appearances.It certainly wouldnt be the first time Kim has been accused of using a stand-in for public events in North Korea.In , the Sun Online revealed images of the dictator chatting with his body doubles at a missile test.He was filmed with two of his lookalikes - dressed identically in his trademark black suit and Cuban heels.Its long been reported paranoid Kim often travels with doubles in a bid to foil assassination attempts.However, some believe this time a lookalike was used because the real Kim is really already DEAD.Others believe it is the same Kim saying he only looks dferent because he has had plastic surgery.And, to add to the mystery, the claims come as the North Korean leader missed yet another high-profile event.He was noticeably absent as Russia awarded him a medal to mark the th anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany.Human rights activist Jenner Zeng was the first to draw attention to dferences in the new Kim, reports IBT.“Is the Kim Jong-un appearing on May  the real one ” she asked on Twitter along with side-by-side comparisons of Kim’s “old and new” appearances in two posts.Another user pointed out that Kim looked slightly dferent during his recent appearance.My theory is either that he died and was replaced by a clone lookalike, or was out of the public eye for so long bc he was recovering from plastic surgery, tweeted anotherHis nose seems a little bit more rounded, his hairline looks wider, and he used to have WAY more wrinkles around the eyes when he smiled, the poster added.The hairline may just be receding or a fresh new haircut, but the smoother eyes and slightly dferent nose have me questioning things.The North Korean despot suddenly reappeared at a fertiliser factory on Friday after vanishing for nearly three weeks sparking claims he had died or was in a coma after a botched story: A RISE in car use during the lockdown by fed-up Brits is troubling, a government scientist has said tonight.Deputy chief scientic adviser Dame Angela McLean warned the number of motor journeys was creeping up.She told the daily No  press conference: For motor vehicles what you see is a pattern that looks a bit like commuting because its low every weekend and we do worry about that creeping up.I think all of us remember that what weve done together which is to stay home has worked to protect the NHS and save lives and as one of the people who looks at this data and thinks about how it fits into how we think about the future it does trouble me that the dark blue line [use of motor vehicles] is creeping up again.Dame Angela said the UK was now trying to emulate the success of the contact tracing policy adopted by South Korea.South Korea is really the place in the world that we can look to and say this works, she said.It is a large country like we are. story: Beijing has been accused of not reacting quickly enough to contain the killer bug, which has killed more than , people globally.The US President has claimed the coronavirus originated from a lab in Wuhan and has suggest China would be punished for the outbreak.The Chinese government has repeatedly denied the growing suggestions the virus came from a lab and not a wet market.British politicians have also been critical of China, which was led to their ambassador to the UK to speak out.Liu Xiaoming said such talks are a political virus. It is not helpful for the international response.China still has questions to answer about where the coronavirus came from, Boris Johnsons spokesman said on Monday.He said: Im not going to comment on intelligence matters.But, he added: Clearly there are questions that need to be answered about the origin and spread of the virus, not least so we can ensure we are better prepared for future global pandemics.Defence Secretary Ben Wallace yesterday said China needed to be transparent and open about the origin of coronavirus.Speaking in on LBC, he said: “Every day I get intelligence bulletins from our agencies around the world. I dont comment on inidual bulletins, what I have and havent seen. That would be wrong.”When askedChina has questions to answer about their coronavirus response, Mr Wallace added: I think it does. The time for the post mortem on this is after we’ve all got it under control and have come through it and our economies are back to normal.“China needs to be open and transparent about what it learnt, it’s shortcomings but also its successes.”Today it was reported that Mr Trump will disclose the origins of the coronavirus, which the government suspects emerged from a Wuhan laboratory, and urged China to to be transparent.We will be reporting very definitively over a period of time, the president said to reporters before departing for a trip to Arizona.We want them to be transparent. story: WIDER coronavirus testing may lead to Brits intentionally infecting themselves with the virus, warn government scientists.It could also fuel a black market in fake results.Rolling out a “game-changing” check showing whether people have been infected and recovered may backfire, experts have warned.Downing Street advisers claim dodgy employers may only hire people who have tested positive for antibodies against the bug.These workers may also be given riskier frontline roles.It could lead to some Brits infecting themselves to get work – or fuelling of a black market in fake test results.A paper drawn up by the scientic pandemic influenza group on behaviour suggested employers might actively discriminate against workers who were not shown to have antibodies.The April  note, said: Some employers may discriminate on the basis of antibody status.This might include not permitting those testing antibody negative toto work or only taking on new staff with antibody positive test results.”Earlier this week, Matt Hancock announced plans to offer millions of Brits a reliable new test that revealsthey have developed immunity to the bug.Ministers are in talks with leading drugs firm Roche Diagnostics about a “very large-scale roll-out” of antibody testing.The firm is ramping up production of the “high quality” blood test, which can tellsomeone has been exposed to Covid-.Government scientists also warned coronavirus infections in China were ten times higher in early February.At the time, Chinese officials claimed there were just over , confirmed cases.But the scientic pandemic influenza operational group suggested the real figure was closer to ,.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits park family friends bubble
story: Ministers are looking at letting people meet up with a small “bubble” of their friends and relatives.Families could also be allowed to leave their home more often, and for longer, in time to soak up the summer sunshine.The proposals are being considered by ministers as they try to carve a path out of the strict lockdown and to a “new normal”.But the ease in restrictions are not expected to be introduced for several weeks as the government sticks to trying to drive down Covid rates as low as possible.Boris Johnson’s official spokesman confirmed Downing Street is looking at loosening restrictions to let Brits enjoy the outdoors.He said: “We’re looking at a range of possible easements of social distancing measures.“Once we have the scientic evidence, we will be able to set out what those arrangements are”.He added: “Broadly the scientic and medical experts have been clear that there is less likelihood of transmission of this disease outdoors than indoors.“That will obviously be something we are considering as part of the review.The PM – who last week declared the UK is “past the peak” of the virus - will set out his plans to ease the lockdown in a major speech on Sunday night.He is not expected to make immediate sweeping changes, but set out a “roadmap” detailing how restrictions may be eased in future.Under the ‘bubble plan’, Brits would be allowed to pick a small number of people to hang out with.Once you have picked your ‘bubble’ you would be under strict orders not to mix with another one.It means grandparents may face a tough choice between which parts of the family to see.While friendships will be tested as people decide who makes the cut.A Scottish government document outlining the plan states: “We are consideringand how we could make changes to allow people to meet with a small number of othersoutside their own household in a group or “bubble” that acts as a single, self-contained unit, without connections to other households or bubbles.“It is possible that this option would be introduced first for outdoor meetings, ahead of any change to permit indoor meetings of the bubble.”You would still have to stick to social distancing rules when you spent time with anyone in your bubble.Andanyone in the group came down with Covid symptoms the others could be ordered to self-isolate for a fortnight.Currently, people are only meant to go outside for essential shopping or their daily exercise.But the document says ministers are considering “changes to allow people to leave their home more often and or for longer”.Factories and a larger array of shops are expected to be among the first wave of businesses allowed back to work when the lockdown eases.Brits could also be allowed to spend more time outside when the lockdown is eased.The plans have been drawn up by Scotland, but so far the devolved regions have worked in lockstep with Westminster on tackling coronavirus.Schools are not expected to reopen all at once under plans to loosen restrictions.Instead there will be a “phased approach” with Year  pupils expected to head back first.Dominic Raab on Tuesday night warned that sending all pupils back to school at the same time would risk a second spike in Covid infections.And the Scottish document warned that hospitals north of the border could be overwhelmed with Covid admissions within weeksall schools reopened.Mr Raab told the Downing Street press conference: “The one thing I can say with confidence is at least today, the evidence has been that we wouldnt be able to open up all schools, without a very real risk that the transmission rate would rise at such a level that we would risk a second spike.“But weve asked Sage for the options on this and will as ever be continued to be guided by the scientic advice we get.He also warned Brits that le will notto normal even after the lockdown is eased.He said: “As we consider the decisions that we will take next to protect le but also to protect our way of le, it’s now clear that the second phase will be dferent.“We will need to adjust to a new normal where we as a society adapt to safe new ways to work, to travel, to interact and to go about our daily lives.“We have never experienced anything like this first stage of Covid- in terms of the scale of the lives lost but also the lockdown it has required.“As we go forward we want to make sure that the next phase is more comfortable, is more sustainable and prevents lasting damage to jobs and livelihoods.”Ministers have been warned that fuming OAPs could revoltthey are treated dferently in the Covid title: vid droplets cough spread double coronavirus social distancing
story: Using a mixture of water and glycerin, researchers made a cough and sneeze jet that mimicked how far particles can travel amid the coronavirus pandemic.Video from the test model shows how far droplets from both a light and heavy cough or sneeze can travel.The video from Florida Atlantic University shows the particles bursting into the air, and spreading farther as time goes on.Using laser lights, researchers were able to show how far the droplets could travel as the dispersal over time.Particles from a heavy cough or sneeze in the experiment traveled three feet in a matter of seconds, and by  seconds had moved nine feet.For a heavy cough, the researchers found that particles can even travel up to  feet, a statement from Florida Atlantic University said.Currently, the CDC recommends people keep a distance of around six feet in an effort to prevent coronavirus spread.The model, however, showed that droplets can travel double that amount.To help curb virus spread, the CDC has advised all people to wear a face mask in public.The Florida researchers said: We found that wearing a face mask doesn’t stop the particles  percent, but it does slow down the cough jets.”There is currently a gap in knowledge over how COVID- spreads as well as a scientic debate about how the disease moves in the air, Stella Batalama, Ph.D., dean of FAU’s College of Engineering and Computer Science said in a statement on the experiment.Batlama said that the visual model shows how important it is for people to take precautions against virus spread.Moreover, it underscores why it is so essential to cover your cough and sneezes and to wear a face mask when you are out in public settings, she said.Other researchers have created visual representations of how far cough particles can spread.One terrying video shows how a single cough can spread across a supermarket, as particles linger in the air for minutes.Another shocking model shows how on a plane, coughs can be spread throughout a cabin.Researchers from the University of Wuhan in China – around where the COVID- outbreak originated – said that coronavirus can linger in the air of crowded places for hours.Our title: clothes factories produce free face masks
story: CLOTHES factories are to start churning out millions of cloth face coverings for Brits to wear to work.Ministers are in secret talks with manufacturers to provide the masks for everyday use as part of the fight against coronavirus.Under the government plans, the new cloth masks will be issued to all key workers for free, from doctors and nurses to teachers.The revelation comes ahead of a planned announcement on masks by Boris Johnson on Sunday, The Sun can also reveal.In a major change of Government policy, the PM will ask people to wear the new cloth masks on public transport and in the workplace where social distancing is dficult.Boris sees wearing masks as a key confidence-building device to persuade nervous Brits to go back to work, No insiders say.The request - as lay he out his ‘unlockdown’ roadmap - will not come into effect immediately, but when it is deemed safe to start easing the current tough Covid- restrictions, expected from the last week of May.To guard against concern that the instruction could see a run on medical grade masks and strip the NHS of vital PPE supplies, Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove has been tasked to lead another major new industrial mobilization.The Sun has learned that contracts are about to be signed with manufacturers abroad to ship in an initial large supply of cloth masks.Talks are also underway with underemployed British clothes makers to switch their idle supply lines to making the masks.Led by Lord Agnew, the plan will see UK manufacturers soon pushing out “many millions a week”.A Whitehall source said last night: “The domestic effort on face coverings is sensible contingency planning to ensure that demand for medical grade PPE is not overwhelmedthe advice were to change”.After a y debate, experts on the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies have told ministers that cloth masks could help limit the spread of coronavirus.Instead of preventing people from catching the disease, they are deemed to be useful in stopping people already infected with it from expelling droplets from their mouth and nose.Giving evidence to MPs, the government’s Chief Scientic Adviser Sir Patrick Vallance told the Commons Health Committee: “Masks may have a marginal positive effect in that situation, or face coverings of some sort might do”.He explained: “The evidence is that essentially a minute at two metres’ contact is about the same risk as six seconds at one metre, so that gives you some idea of why the two metres becomes important.“And the risk at one metre is about  to  times higher than the risk at two metres, so the distancing is an important part of this. Where, therefore, masks may have a role is in situations where distancing is not possible.”Signalling his thinking on masks last week, Mr Johnson said they “will be useful” when Britain begins to emerge from lockdown.But Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab also voiced fears about how the move could hurt the NHS without a major new supply of them.Mr Raab told the daily No press conference: “We do not want to detract from the supply of masks and PPE going to frontline workers”.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: furlough help only poorest workers
story: Only the most financially desperate workers would be kept on the Government’s wage support scheme under draft plans to wind it down after June, The Sun can reveal.Rishi Sunak is looking at targeting the furlough scheme at certain age groups and the worst-hit sectors as part of plans to gradually wean workers off the state-subsidised wage support.The Chancellor is also considering cutting the  per cent wage subsidy to  per cent, which would cut income by up to £ a month. The scheme could then be reduced even further over coming months - encouraging people to look for new jobs.The changes being considered are focused on “incentivising work,” a source said.Mr Sunak is expected to announce how the job retention scheme will change after June next week.He wants to give firms certainty about the scheme beyond June and making an announcement by the end of next week is key because employers who are planning to make staff redundant in July must give  days notice. The deadline for this is May .The Sun understands that options being considered include only making the job retention scheme available to workers who the Treasury deem as most financially unstable.This could include renters who are living “hand-to-mouth” each month and whose large proportion of income goes on rent and bills. They are also less protected than homeowners, who are eligible for mortgage holidays. Although tenants can only apply for rental deferrals, landlords are not obliged to comply, while the move would also help prevent them being evicted due to unpaid rent.This could be administered by targeting certain age groups, such as millennials - workers in their s and s who are much more likely to rent.This idea would help young workers stay attached to their current jobs and help protect their future job prospects.Treasury insiders said changes to the scheme could see only workers in sectors that are deemed vital to protect kept on the furlough scheme.This could also allow the Treasury to keep workers furloughed in industries that are likely to be closed longer-term, such as pubs, restaurants, hotels and the tourism industry in general.But industry experts warned that this would cause problems for small businesses that don’t fit into one sector.Federation of Small Businesses chief Mike Cherry warned: “Government must avoid applying a sector straightjacket that doesn’t work for small firms – there are far too many businesses who don’t fit neatly into one box who will need time to get back up and running – like small companies that mainly supply to hotels but aren’t hospitality businesses.”The Treasury is also looking at allowing furloughed employees to work part-time. The Government’s subsidy would be smaller under this option, but it would avoid employers being forced to bar staff from working in order to be eligible for the wage support.The Treasury has said that designing a part-time furlough scheme would be much harder to administer.But officials have told industry groups that it is possible and they are waiting for “political direction”.The FSB’s Mr Cherry urged the Chancellor to prioritise working on finding a part-time furlough scheme that would offer businesses maximum flexibility as they attempt to reopen in the coming weeks.He said: “Small firms must be allowed to get back on their feet one step at a time –  million jobs depend on it.“It’s a dficult situation, but the only feasible option is to allow part time furloughing where furloughed staff canto work for part of their contracted hours. This will enable small employers to stagger back theof their staff at a time when we know economic activity will be at record low levels.”He added: “We need to see these changes made from the beginning of June as small businesses restart. Orders are going unfulfilled because a few hours work doesn’t justy bringing somebody off furlough. Businesses can’t even quote for jobs once lockdown lts. Time is of the essence.”News of the plans to tweak the job retention scheme come after Mr Sunak confirmed earlier this week that he was working on the best way to gradually close it down, which is currently due to run until the end of June.He told ITV News: To anyone anxious about this, I want to reassure that there will be no clf-edge to the furlough scheme.Im working as we speak to figure out the most effective way to wind down the scheme and ease people back into work in a measured way.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new shift patterns coronavirus
story: WORKPLACES should operate new sht patterns that would see staff in work four days followed by  days working from home, a new report recommends.The study by Imperial College London chemical biologist Professor Keith Willison for the Adam Smith Institute would split workforces into two groups that never overlap.The ‘cyclical’ proposal is designed to help the Government restart the economy in a Covid-friendly environment.The traditional Saturday and Sunday weekend would no longer apply.Instead workers’ two-day weekends would sht according to the pattern.One group of the workforce would work for four consecutive days, followed by  days in lockdown.In the second week the other half of the group are able to attend with ten days in lockdown after that.The same could be applied to schools, with children’s days in the classroom coinciding with their parents’ days in the office in order to solve childcare issues.The report by the Adam Smith Institute urges the Government to move away from a binary understanding of open and closed businesses to think about the ied ways organisation could reopen.It argues that its proposal would allow the UK to meet three fundamental goals.It would minimise the risk of a second peak, enable maximum possibleto business and educational normality while keeping iniduals safe and would provide the public reassurance about safety concerns.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lets get britain sewing
story: WE understand why scared Brits aren’t champing at the bit toto work.For nearly two months they’ve been told that staying at home saves lives and going out puts them in jeopardy.That’s all changing now: hospital admissions are down below , a day for the first time since March , and the NHS no longer looks in danger of being overwhelmed.But it’s only natural that workers remain cautious. If Boris Johnson is to get our flatlining economy going again, he and his Government must prove to the public that lockdown restrictions can be lted sensibly and safely.And that’s where homemade masks come in. Yes, we know they’re not perfect. But mounting evidence proves that insisting on their use in confined spaces can help slow the spread of the virus, and — crucially — they lend confidence.One way or another, it’s becoming crystal clear that after lockdown Britain will be very dferent from the country we remember. Gone are the days of a post-work pint in the pub to wind down:ministers permit us to socialise, it will be only for picnics, and only with those we consider our close friends.But with the economy on its knees, we must throw everything we’ve got at creating a “new normal” to tide us over until a vaccine can be found.Andmasks are part of that, then let’s get Britain sewing.OFFICIALS must stop hiding behind corona-jargon and start explaining in plain English exactly what they want from us.Guidance states thatyou’re classed as “extremely clinically vulnerable” you’re supposed to “shield”, andyou’re considered “clinically vulnerable” you should be “closely following social distancing rules”.The problem is thatyou’re over  and not in the habit of scrutinising government websites, you may understandably not know what the dference between those terms is. And so could be putting yourself through the misery of a  week self-isolation unnecessarily.Brits have given up most of their cherished liberties at the drop of a hat. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe government is gripped by a row over how over-s will be treated when lockdown starts to ease. At the moment, people over  are under pretty much the same rules as the rest of the population. The vast majority can go out for exercise, do essential shopping and pick up medicine - they just have to be more careful than everyone . But campaigners fear that when lockdown is relaxed, older people might be kept under the rules for longer than younger people, for their own safety. That proposal - which has been rumoured but is not in any way confirmed by government - has sparked a backlash among doctorsapos leaders and campaigners. Here are the current rules explained, and what might or might not happen in the future. No. Most over-s are subject to the same lockdown rules that apply to everyone  in the UK. In other words, they can go out for four reasons - essential shopping, exercise once a day, a medical need or work. The dference between over-s and the rest of the UK is they are classed as clinically vulnerable. That dference, however, just means they should be particularly stringent in following lockdown rules. The rules themselves are not tougher for over-s. However, some over-s have been told to stay at home completely for  weeks and not leave, even for exercise or shopping. These are people with a serious health condition who the NHS has told to shield themselves from society. More on this below.  My relative is over . How do I knowtheyaposre allowed to leave home or not  For now, the government has split over-s into two groups: clinically vulnerable and extremely clinically vulnerable.    Who is aposextremely clinically vulnerableapos  The extremely clinically vulnerable group is .million people who have a specic, serious health condition that puts them in danger from Covid-. These people are being shielded - in other words, must not leave their house for  weeks even for exercise. They should rely on neighbours, family or a government helpline for supplies. This group is not defined by age. But by its very nature it does include lots of people over . It includes people undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy, anyone with cystic fibrosis or COPD, or those with signicant heart conditions. A full list is here, butyou are in the shielded group you should have been contacted. Who is aposclinically vulnerableapos  The clinically vulnerable group is all other over-s. They are still at higher risk, but the only dference is they should take particular care to minimise contact with others outside their own home. Other than this, they are allowed to leave home in the same way as other people during lockdown.

title: cuddly dad who swapped fast
story: NewsCuddly st dad who swapped fast food for home meals shows off transformationWhen Mark Smith, , agreed to a lads skiing trip, it was game on. After swapping fast food for home made meals and going to the gym with we Sarah, hes lost over stShareCommentsByMark Smith:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMark Smith used to enjoy takeaways and would rarely exercise" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWith a grin on my face and a sideways glance at my we, Sarah, I was off – racing to outsprint her to the end of the gym. We touched the wall at the same time, panting, and I couldn’t help smiling. There was a time when tying with Sarah in a race would have been unimaginable – as would being in the gym with her. As we headed for a pick-me-up coffee, I reflected on how dferent my mornings were. Just a year before, at over st, I’d get out of breath on the stairs. When the alarm went off I’d see Sarah swinging out of bed and grabbing her gym kit. She’d ask me to join her, but I’d say, ‘No thanks, you enjoy it,’ before burrowing back under the duvet. When I woke again, I always wished I’d gone. I didn’t like being the ‘cuddly dad’ in a family of fit women.Sarah was smashing four gym sessions a week our eldest daughter, Jodie, then , ran fitness classes and Emma at  was an incredible dancer who’d won a national street dance competition as a teenager. I’d always been ‘Big Smiggy’ – a childhood nickname – but I could never find motivation to lose weight. In April , at around st, a series of events put me on the path to change. On a family grave visit, I saw the marble gravestone had toppled over. When I tried to pull it up something gave way with a snap. An operation to repair my distal tendon, detached at the forearm, didn’t go to plan. A nerve was trapped and I ended up with agonising radial nerve palsy and on strong painkillers. I was off work for eight months, watching endless TV and eating takeaways.  Even back at work, I carried on eating more fast food than before and began hiding things from Sarah, filling up on burgers or pizza on the way home, ahead of the dinner she was cooking. I’d been feeling tired all the time, so I had a check-up. My doctor seemed concerned and took blood tests. When I went to get the results, I could tell by his face that it wasn’t good news. He said my heart attack risk was raised, I had pre-diabetes and fatty liver tissue, and unhealthy cholesterol levels. But I still wasn’t in the right headspace to tackle my weight. Even when one day out with Sarah it struck me I’d stopped holding her hand because I thought she might be ashamed to be seen with me. Then a year later a work colleague told me he was going to try Slimming World to lose some weight for a friend’s wedding. I’d always thought it was for women.  Before I knew it, I’d agreed to go with him – a decision I regretted telling my mates about in the pub. I got a ribbing and was told ‘just cut down on the beer. Maybe that way you can fit into a ski suit.’ The lads had always gone skiing together, but I could never picture myself tackling a ski slope. How all that was to change. In February , I nervously went to Slimming World with my workmate only to find everyone so welcoming – but it was a shock when I tipped the scales at st ½lbs, much heavier than I thought. To give me extra motivation, I agreed to go on a  ski trip to Poland with the lads. That first week, I was so desperate to see the scales move I barely ate anything, ignoring advice from my Consultant Kate. Back at the group, I’d lost a lot of weight, but I felt weak and shaky. Kate took me aside for a quiet word, and when I told her I’d pretty much been living on fruit, she patiently went through the Food Optimising plan with me again. She promised meI stuck to the plan it would work, and after a week of eating proper food, I felt a lot more like myself – and I’d lost another ½lbs. I got stuck into the plan properly, and in five weeks I’d lost st. Soon, I developed an interest in food I’d never had before. Fish became my favourite thing to cook at home and Sarah enthusiastically threw herself into preparing meals with me.  I gave up my secret takeaways, cut back on the cans of lager and made healthy, satisfying dishes with help from Sarah – like salmon or cod with pak choi, kale, spinach and rice. Soon, with all the tips and recipe ideas I got at the group, I found I loved rustling up home-made burger and chips with salad, or a quick chicken curry with plenty of fresh chilli and coriander. In the mornings, I’d have poached eggs, beans, mushrooms fried in low-calorie cooking spray and low-fat chicken sausages. And even though I was eating way more than Sarah and the girls, I was still losing weight. A couple of months after I joined the group, Jodie askedI’d go to her weekend gym classes. I agreed. I kept myself to the back row of her Bodyattack class and felt exhausted after lots of sit-ups, press-ups, squat jumps and other high-energy exercises – but also exhilarated. “How was that ” Jodie asked. ‘Awful,” I deadpanned. “When’s the next one ”  In the group, Kate had been talking about activity a lot, and now I’d survived Jodie’s class, I’d proved to myself maybe I was ready for it. So, when Sarah’s am alarm went off the following Monday, I got out of bed and put on my gym kit. The class she had in store sounded taxing – high-intensity interval training. But I actually enjoyed myself, especially as Sarah and I were doing it together. Cooking healthy meals and exercising regularly was really paying off, and I was beginning to look leaner. My mates certainly noticed, and started messaging me for meal advice and recipe recommendations. “I think I miss my big cuddly dad a little bit,” Emma teased. Sarah had also lost a couple of stones just by eating Slimming World meals with me, and losing weight together gave our relationship an added spark. We now trained together four times a week, doing Bodyattack, boxercise and HIIT classes, cooked and ate together each day and at the weekend we’d take our two dogs, Honey and Bella, on long walks along the beach.

It was actually really lovely as we could just concentrate on us and our vows, and not have to split our time between the guests. It was sad that we couldn’t have any family there as they live too far away. But we feel incredibly lucky to have been able to get married before lockdown.  “We are going to have our full celebration next year as our first wedding anniversary.” The couple walked down the aisle to the Toy Story song “You’ve Got a Friend in Me”, and after the ceremony, which took place outside overlooking the rolling hills, Katherine and Alex, , celebrated by having champagne with some rather more unusual guests - the farm’s resident llamas. Becky and Sam Bride-to-be Becky Storey and fiance Sam Beckham found out three weeks before their wedding day that it would have to be cancelled. They were devastated that they weren’t going to be able to share their big day with their  family and friends at Doxford Barns in Northumberland, so decided to take control and have their own mini-wedding.  Becky’s niece and nephew Scarlett and Max are living with the couple at the moment as their parents are frontline workers, so Scarlett donned her bridesmaid dress and Max officiated as the registrar as the couple said their vows to each other. Council worker Becky, , explains: “We were just devastated when we got the news that the wedding couldn’t go ahead as planned. But everything happened so quickly with the virus and things just don’t seem real at the moment, so realised we probably wouldn’t have wanted to get married under these circumstances. “We decided to take ownership of the situation and turn a negative into a positive. We wanted to mark what would have been our wedding day and turn a sad day into a happy one.  “I ordered some decorations online and we decorated the house. I wore a white dress I already had and Sam wore a suit, and we said some vows to each other and exchanged our rings. “Some of our friends and family drove by our house with gts to cheer us up and it actually did feel really special.” Becky and web designer Sam, , shared a video and pictures of their home ceremony online and have received hundreds of messages of support. They have now rearranged their actual wedding for April  next year.  Lizzie and Richard Lizzie Hargreaves never expected to be cooking steak and chips in her wedding dress, but that is exactly what happened when she and finance Richard Sisson had to hastily bring their big day forward. The couple are big practical jokers, so didn’t tell a soul they were planning to get married on April Fool’s Day - even their kids were in the dark. But with lockdown looming, their wedding venue Nottingham Forest Football ground urged them to bring it forward to March . Lizzie says: “No-one ever expected me and Richard to get married, so it was supposed to be one big April Fool’s joke on everyone and the joke ended up being on us.”  They rapidly rearranged and got special permission from the registrars to allow Lizzie’s three children jack, , Noah, nine and Alice, six to attend as well as Lizzie’s mum Alison and her partner Ron. Nottingham Forest even let them tie the knot in the ground’s boardroom with all the club’s silverware in there as a special treat. Lizzie, , who runs an online gt company, explains: “I think it made it more memorable because of the circumstances. Even the two registrars cried and they said they never cry at weddings. I think it was because we all knew that the world was going to change dramatically after that day.” Unfortunately police officer Richard’s parents had flown in from Spain and had to self-isolate so couldn’t attend, and the couple had to cancel their planned reception at a local restaurant to protect Lizzie’s parents.  Lizzie says: “We just went home and I cooed steak and chips in my wedding dress and we had some champagne. It wasn’t what we had planned but we certainly have a story to tell. We just feel so fortunate to have actually been able to get married as so many couples haven’t.” Holly and Endrit Holly Lynch and Endrit Shehu had been planning their wedding for a year when lockdown meant it couldn’t go ahead. They were due to tie the knot in Albania where Endrit’s family live, but the ban on international travel made it impossible. So the couple from Colne in Lancashire decided they had to still mark the date with a virtual zoom wedding for all their family and friends from around the world.  Holly, , explains: “We met in Zante  years ago - Endrit’s family lived there and I was doing a summer season. It was a typical holiday romance. We had planned the wedding in Albania and it would have been the first time most of our family and friends would have met. “We were devastated when we realised it wouldn’t happen, but also we are very aware what a strange situation we are living in and that there are people a lot worse off than us. We are in a global pandemic.”  So on April , what would have been their wedding day, fitness manager Holly wore a white dress and her wedding Jimmy Choo shoes, and personal trainer Endrit, , donned his best suit to say “I do” online. Holly says: “We set up a zoom call and we thought it might last a couple of hours. But it was amazing and turned into a real riot. It went on until about am. In Albania the wedding tradition is to do lots of dancing, so Endrit’s parents led the dancing and people were all dancing in their front rooms.  “Endrit’s best men told funny stories about him, as did my Maid of Honour. It was really, really good. It felt like everyone connected - all of our family and friends from all over the world, with so many dferent cultures. We are really glad we marked the occasion in that way and everyone has now already met virtually ahead of the real thing in Albania next year.” Jacqui and Andrew Instead of having family and friends as witnesses to their wedding Jacqui Keiss and Andrew Reed had their pet budgies Jabba and RD watch them tie the knot. The couple got engaged on Christmas Day  and were supposed to wed at a local restaurant on April  this year, but when lockdown happened they had to postpone until August . So the pair who live in Glasgow decided to go ahead and say their vows in secret in their own front room on what would have been their big day - and then surprised all their family and friends.  Jacqui wore a lilac dress she already had at home, and Andrew, , who works in the NHS, donned a suit before they said their vows and cracked open a bottle of champagne they had been given as an engagement present. Jacqui, , who works in digital marketing, says: “We were getting married that day no matter what. When we got engaged we had planned to elope so I suppose this worked in our favour. And before the wedding was postponed we were worried that my brother and his family who live in Switzerland wouldn’t be able to make it. “I couldn’t get my wedding dress and Andrew couldn’t get his kilt as they shops were shut, so we just had to wear something we already had. But it was romantic - it was just us two and our budgies as witnesses.

title: polly hudon covid tears thing
story: NewsopinionPolly Hudon: Covid Tears are a thing, let them fall and reset your mindSome mornings, despite my best efforts, I wake up completely flooded with hopelessness, and then I just wait for them to come, but after crying Covid Tears I feel oddly cleansed, says mirror columnist Polly HudsonShareCommentsByPolly Hudson:,  MAY NewsopinionLet the Covid Tears come" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThere’s definitely an element of be careful what you wish for about the current situation. Who amongst us hasn’t at some point longed for the pace of modern le to slow down a bit, to spend more time with their family, for a few more quiet nights in  And now we’ve got it. People also often wish they could go back to their carefree, responsibility-lite childhoods, as well. The best days of your le and all that. Well, great news – we’ve got that, too. Thanks to lockdown, we are now kids again. We’ve been transported back to when someone  made our decisions for us and we had no say about anything. We have to do what we’re told, relinquish control, and put all our trust in those looking after us.  Feeling like we’ve regressed to being five years old does at least make sense of why so many of us have been acting like it recently.Sulking, throwing tantrums, not playing nicely with the others, particularly those who stand less than two metres away. Having puppy fat. Who hasn’t ranted and wailed about the rules – even just in our heads – despite them being for our own good, ie saving lives  We’re going to bed early, doing jigsaws, walking around looking like our mums cut our hair with kitchen scissors.  And then – maybe it’s just me – there’s the crying. If coronavirus hasn’t utterly devastated us – emotionally, financially, or both – yet – we are grateful. Trying to keep busy, being positive, looking ahead. But every now and then I can’t help but wobble. And then come the Covid Tears. Some mornings, despite my best efforts, I wake up completely flooded with hopelessness, and then I just wait for them to come.They’re a short, melodramatic flash of depression. There’s probably a psychological term for them, and an explanation about how they happen in times of exceptional stress, when the reality of what is going on is, in the very truest sense of the word, overwhelming. It’s like a volcano of feelings, which has been bubbling away for a while, suddenly erupting. The way to deal with Covid Tears – and the fact we’re all scared, all the time – is to embrace the childhood we have been forced to revert to.  Make like a five year old.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFriends and family may soon be allowed to meet up in a small aposbubbleapos for picnics under new plans being drawn up to ease the coronavirus lockdown. The government is considering letting a small group mingle and families may be allowed to leave their homes more often and for longer in time for summer. The proposals are being considered by ministers as they try to steer the nation into adopting a “new normal” routine. But any changes will not be rolled out for several weeks as the government want to see the number of Covid- cases decrease further, Sun Online reports. Prime Minster Boris Johnson ’s official spokesman confirmed ministers are looking at easing the lockdown so Brits can enjoy being outdoors in the sunshine.to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at mirror email -after the press conference every evening. He said: “Once we have the scientic evidence, we will be able to set out what those arrangements are. “Broadly the scientic and medical experts have been clear that there is less likelihood of transmission of this disease outdoors than indoors. “That will obviously be something we are considering as part of the review. Mr Johnson announced last week that the nation was past the peak of the killer virus and was working on his plans to loosen restrictions which he will reveal in a major speech on Sunday. A Scottish government document outlining the plan states: “We are consideringand how we could make changes to allow people to meet with a small number of othersoutside their own household in a group or “bubble” that acts as a single, self-contained unit, without connections to other households or aposbubblesapos. “It is possible that this option would be introduced first for outdoor meetings, ahead of any change to permit indoor meetings of the bubble.”  Under the aposbubble planapos people would be allowed to pick a small number of friends and family to mix with but will not be allowed to mingle with anyone . Relationships with family members and friendships will be tested as people decide who they want in their bubble while grandparents could face a painful dilemma when choosing. Everyone would still need to adhere to social distancing measures when mixing in their bubble. In addition,anyone in the group starts to suffer from coronavirus symptoms the others could be ordered to self-isolate for a fortnight. Current rules only allow people to leave their homesthey are a key worker, to do essential shopping or for their daily exercise. But ministers are considering “changes to allow people to leave their home more often and or for longer”.  Factories and more shops are expected to be among the first phase of businesses allowed to reopen when the lockdown eases. The plans have been drawn up by Scotland, but so far the devolved regions have worked with Westminster on tackling coronavirus. Schools are not expected to reopen all at once under the plans instead kids will be phased back in with Year  pupils expected to go back first. Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab warned on Tuesday that sending pupils back to school at the same time could fuel a second spike in coronavirus cases. And the Scottish document backs up his fears as it states hospitals north of the border could be overwhelmed with Covid- admissions within weeksall schools reopened. Mr Raab told the Downing Street press conference: “The one thing I can say with confidence is at least today, the evidence has been that we wouldnapost be able to open up all schools, without a very real risk that the transmission rate would rise at such a level that we would risk a second spike.  “But weaposve asked Sage for the options on this and will as ever be continued to be guided by the scientic advice we get. Issuing a warning that le will notto normal after the lockdown is eased, he said: “We will need to adjust to a new normal where we as a society adapt to safe new ways to work, to travel, to interact and to go about our daily lives. “We have never experienced anything like this first stage of Covid- in terms of the scale of the lives lost but also the lockdown it has required. “As we go forward we want to make sure that the next phase is more comfortable, is more sustainable and prevents lasting damage to jobs and livelihoods.”  The news comes as senior government science advisor resigned on Tuesday after breaking lockdown social distancing rules to meet his lover. Professor Neil Ferguson sat on the governmentaposs SAGE committee, which provides advice to ministers on their response to the pandemic and told Mr Johnson a lockdown was the best way to tackle the killer virus.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDame Vera Lynn has performed her most iconic hit thousands of times in the past nine decades. She has sung it on radio, TV, and film, in the Royal Albert Hall and outside Buckingham Palace. But just after pm on Friday, she will open the living room window of her home in Ditchling, East Sussex, and sing it again with a new passion. And, as the strains of We’ll Meet Again ring out into the evening air, Dame Vera will be thinking of all those brave fighting men she met and performed for during our darkest hours. For, while the whole nation marks the th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day, the -year old Forces Sweetheart will feel it with particular poignancy. “I still think about those boys you know,” she reveals quietly. “And I’ve never stopped wondering how many of them actually made it home.” Her  record became a wartime anthem of love, hope and resilience. And when the Queen quoted it in her pandemic address to the nation, last month, it took on new signicance in this very dferent war. So Dame Vera – who was made a Companion of Honour to the Queen in  – joined forces with Welsh mezzo-soprano Katherine Jenkins and released a duet of the song to raise money for NHS workers and volunteers. And Friday’s VE Day commemorations will culminate with a nationwide rendition of We’ll Meet Again. “It will be lovely,” says Dame Vera. “I hope it will give us all strength and hope in these dficult times. But it’s also about remembering the sacrices of the war, and the sense of release on May , .” On that day Dame Vera was back home in Barking, East London, with her parents and grandmother. “We were in our garden listening to the wireless when it was announced,” she says. “We sat in the sun thinking ‘What wonderful news!’ We were thrilled. I don’t think we shed a tear though, you did that privately. People didn’t show their emotions.  “I think we had a cup of tea, perhaps later a sherry. We raised a toast with our neighbours across the garden fence.” A year before Dame Vera had been in the Far East, entertaining troops at a crucial point in the Burma Campaign. Hearing her sing The White Clfs of Dover, A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square and There’ll Always Be an England boosted the morale of the “forgotten” th Army, whose heroism in the jungles went largely overlooked during the war itself. So on Friday she will think particularly of the men who were still fighting in the Far East as the VE Day celebrations in Blighty got under way.  Looking at an album of treasured photos, she recalls: “I wasn’t allowed to take my own camera with me to Burma but after I got home all the boys started sending me their pictures. “That’s why my daughter and I wrote our book, Keep Smiling Through, about my time there. A lot found it hard to speak about the war and I used to get lots of letters from their families. Unless you experienced it you had no idea what it was like. “That’s why it’s so important that schools teach children what it was all about. So we never, ever forget.” Dame Vera grew up in East London with dressmaker mum Annie, plumber dad Bert and elder brother Roger.  She began singing in working men’s clubs at the age of seven and, in her teens, was working with big bands such as the Joe Loss Orchestra. At  she released her first record, Up the Wooden Hill to Bedfordshire, and when war broke out she was already a radio favourite. In , her Sunday night radio show Sincerely Yours became a morale booster for troops and their families. She had met husband Harry Lewis in the s while they were both in the Bert Ambrose Orchestra. They married in  and had a daughter, Virginia, in . Harry died in .  “I think of him every day,” says Vera, “He was the love of my le.” Early in the war, newspaper readers voted Vera their Forces Sweetheart. “It came as a surprise,” she says. “I’d always tried to imagine I was sitting at home by the fire, singing to people in the same room. But I became a messenger, linking separated people. It is very humbling. “I saw it as my duty to keep on singing. I thought that tag would disappear after the war and I’d just be another singer.”  Perhaps she would,she had not taken the brave step to go and sing for troops in Egypt, India and Burma in , aged . “I wanted to go where I was most needed,” she says. Getting to Burma involved a gruelling ,-mile trip via the USA, with her pianist, piano and a pistol. She then spent four months in a camp entertaining the troops as the bloody Battle of Kohima raged nearby. “It was nice to meet them in person,” she says. “I liked being one of them, living in a tent with one bucket for washing and one for the toilet. “I was never the glamorous type like Betty Grable. My make-up would run off in the heat so I only bothered with a lipstick.”
