title: newstead-shows-incredible-kindness-lockdown
story: While the Borders adapts to the challenges posed by lockdown, community spirit is in full flow across the region. Newstead is no exception, with residents pulling together to help anyone in need.ldquoA small group of us recently came together, says Lisa Cowan, who coordinates the village resilience effort. ldquoWith such a high number of older people living in the village, we anticipated many may need extra support.A Facebook group called lsquoNewstead Village Chatrsquo group was soon launched, allowing the chance to share ideas and offer help. The group now boasts more than  members, according to Lisa.She says: ldquoThe Facebook group is a big success, but we quickly realised more needed to be done."As supermarket shelves were stripped, older people continued to head out looking for supplies. We felt there must be another way to help high risk groups."Equally, local businesses were worried about the virus affecting their trade. In order to help sustain all aspects of our community, wersquove tried to take a broad approach.One solution was the creation of the first Newstead Village Newsletter ndash a simple, four-page leaflet which included useful information and several helpline numbers. ldquoMelrose shops offering home deliveries were also included in the newsletter, says Lisa. ldquoWe put the information online but that excluded those without internet access. So, a printed version delivered to every home was essential.Local Volvo dealer John Cleland kindly offered to take care of the printing, while Gala Le said they would deliver. But these exciting plans looked to be scuppered with the imposition of lockdown.Thankfully, though, postman Keith Borthwick came to the rescue, explained Lisa.She says: "He made sure that every house received a copy of the newsletter with their mail. Feedback has been brilliant. Itrsquos proving a great resource to help people access local shops.The village has also created a highly productive WhatsApp group, which is proving to be a "great way" to keep in touch with residents in isolation, says local volunteer Sonia Kelly.ldquoShoppers message when theyrsquore heading out, and those in need then get in contact," says Sonia. "The system works well and is based on being neighbourly. Therersquos so much community activity taking place, itrsquos bringing everyone together in the most resourceful way.Jane McNeil is also one of Newsteadrsquos busy shoppers. ldquoI started volunteering because I wanted to help those who had made me feel welcome since moving to the village," she says."It started with a couple of neighbours and has grown since then. Irsquom a great believer in treating others as I would hope to be treated. With so many new friendships being forged, my hope is that after the pandemic, we can maintain this level of care for our neighbours.Another shopper is Jackie Kerr, who helps out a couple of the villages older residents. ldquoI shop a few times a week for Nancy Howieson, who is , and her mother Georgina Paterson ndash who recently celebrated her th birthday. They live separately and are usually very independent. So, itrsquos a dficult time for them now, but Irsquom happy to help in any way I can.Nancy and Georgina are well known around Melrose, where they founded Tweedbank Art Club and put on regular shows. ldquoWe love to paint, says Nancy. ldquoWe are the best of friends and usually see each other every day. Mum has led an exciting le including travelling the world and being a maid at Buckingham Palace for Princess Alice. Shersquos a bit fed up as she likes to get out but is still managing to paint.Whilst her mother continues to paint her way through the lockdown, Nancy has been busy tackling her garden. ldquoI try not to bother folk, but my next-door neighbour has been such a help offering to cut my grass and digging out some tree roots. Everyone in the village is being really friendly.With so many currently living in isolation, volunteers are also reaching out by phone. ldquoIf people arenrsquot on the Internet, itrsquos easy for them to be left out, says Liz Ellis, who has lived in Newstead for  years. ldquoTherefore a few of us are making regular phone calls to people all over the village just to say hello, seethey need anything and have a friendly chat. Irsquove never experienced anything like this in Newstead before. I canrsquot get over the amount of support being offered everyone is desperate to help each other.,params: .pushThe Neate family are also playing their role in raising village spirits. Toby, aged nine, and his seven-year-old brother Rueben, along with other Newstead children, have been displaying colourful paintings in their windows and have decorated the village phone box with rainbows. ldquoIt makes us really happy that our art is helping to keep the village smiling, says Toby.Meanwhile, dad Tristan, who manages Neate Maintenance, has offered to help Newsteadrsquos army of NHS workers. ldquoThe pandemic is putting pressure on many key workers who are working extremely long hours. Im sure they have little time for gardening right now. In , Irsquod like to thank them by volunteering to their cut grass or do some weeding.Lisa, the resilience co-ordinator, says shes "never felt prouder" of the village.ldquoCoordinating the resilience group is a pleasure," she says. "Wersquore seeing so many incredible acts of kindness, often between complete strangers. Itrsquos heart-warming to be part of such a generous community.

title: borders-businesses-get-16-5m-coronavirus-support-funding
story: BORDERS businesses will have soon collectively received more than pound. million from the council as they struggle through the coronavirus pandemic.Scottish Borders Councilis managing a portion of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Business Support Fund.A total of , businesses have been approved for help so far, with payments taking the form of one-off grants worth pound, and pound,.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoApplications continue to be received for the Business Support Fund and I would encourage any eligible businesses to make sure they apply so they can receive the funding support they are entitled to.ldquoWe estimate that around , local businesses are eligible, therefore about half have already been successful in obtaining support.ldquoWe anticipate that early next week detailed information and guidance regarding the additional financial support announced by the Scottish Government will be available and as such application forms and criteria will be available from our dedicated web pages at www.scotborders.gov.uk covidbusiness.

title: girl-15-tells-people-stay-positive-short-film
story: A TEENAGER has made a short film to encourage people to be ldquopositive during the coronavirus pandemic.Emillie Jo Galbraith, , created the stop-motion video after noticing some of her friends had become unmotivated under lockdown.Emillie Jo urges viewers to adopt a can-do attitude and remain hopeful.The Biggar residenttold us: ldquoI just really wanted to help people and spread a positive message.The aspiring doctor made the video on April , using her iPhone to capture hundreds of images before editing them into a sequence and adding a voiceover.After posting the end result online, Emillie Jo was delighted to find her message quickly securing support.ldquoItrsquos gone really well, she said, reflecting on the feedback. ldquoNHS Lanarkshire have put it up on their Facebook page and it had a lot of really lovely comments.Outlining how she was inspired to craft the video in the first place, she said she had become aware of a growing negativity among her friends.She said: ldquoThey saw this time asthey were trapped and stuck inside and they were unmotivated to get up out of bed and make their day count so I wanted to help them.ldquoI wanted to help brighten up their day and help them see that this time isnrsquot just a negative time and that there is positivity, there always is - it can sometimes be dficult to see, but it is there.Emillie Jo revealed that she places a high value on looking after mental health, adding: ldquoWe need positivity, we need to be resilient.She said: ldquoLike I said in my video, future generations will be looking back at us as not the negative bunch, but the resilient people who got through one of the most challenging times.Emillie Jos video can be watched through this link.

title: borders-college-staff-create-visors-key-workers
story: STAFF at Borders College are supporting frontline workers by making face shields.Assistant principal Davie Lowe and lecturer Mark Catto took home the colleges D printers so they could create headbands and attach acetate shields.The visors are being distributed to care homes by Scottish Borders Council during the coronavirus pandemic.Mr Lowe said: ldquoIrsquod seen that other schools and colleges were utilising their D printers for this, so we decided that, as wersquove got D printers, we could use them.ldquoOur colleague Paul Watson, from Eyemouth High School, shared an approved open-source programme for creating the headband, which allowed us to get these into production.ldquoBetween Mark and myself, we hope to produce over  face shields a week.Last Friday , at the end of their first week making the visors, the pair had produced .The D printers take up to one hour to build up the layers of plastic that create the headband. The acetate screens then attached are made using lamination pouches.Mr Lowe said: ldquoThe process is fairly straightforward and, in fact, my we Yvonne is keeping the production going when I am working in the other room.The shields act as a physical barrier to protect health care workersrsquo faces, and D printer owners around the world are uniting to create an international network of DIY manufacturing.Mr Catto, a construction and STEM lecturer, said: "As my we works at the Borders General Hospital, I can see first-hand the impact this virus is having.ldquoAny small way that can support the NHS at this time can only be beneficial.ldquoI have also got my eight-year-old son Alasdair helping out with the D printing and assembly of the visors.

title: galashiels-town-band-mark-date-declaration-night
story: MUSICIANS gave a socially-distanced performance on their doorsteps to mark what would have been the Declaration Night for the Braw Lads Gathering.Despite the official event being cancelled, members of Galashiels Town Band decided they should still honour the occasion.Band chairman Neal Wade said: "We thought we should do this for morale ndash we are the towns band, after all."Last Friday , a total of  band members lted the towns spirits with their rendition, played from inidual gardens and doorsteps.The tune was re-written, said Mr Wade, to allow musicians of all ages to participate.Chairman of the Braw Lads Gathering Craig Whitehead said: "I would like to personally thank the Galashiels Town Band for playing inidually from their homes on Friday night at pm."It was a super idea and the compilation of the video was very special indeed."Unfortunately we had to cancel this years Gathering due to the COVID- situation, but itrsquos great to see support like this towards the Braw Ladsrsquo Gathering."We will continue to keep our Facebook and Twitter accounts up to date over the next few months with #throwbackthursday."The bands musical director is now providing online lessons, with plans in place for the group to record their own parts to a tune and combine them later.Mr Wade added: "Its not the year we expected, but you cant keep the band down ndash Im very proud of them. Next year will be fantastic."To watch the bands performance from Declaration Night, you can click here.

title: borders-professor-moots-return-national-service
story: A BORDERS professor has asked the UK Government to consider bringing back National Service.In an article published this week by The Times, military historian Sir Hew Strachan, Lord-Lieutenant of Tweeddale, was quoted from his report issued to the Ministry of Defence.In his report, Sir Hew said that bringing back National Service, which was phased out in , could help people better discuss the role of the military in the UK.The report also suggests that the military is expressed more like "a mythologised memory of the Second World War than an appreciation of armed conflict as it is experienced and conducted today.Tweeddale MP David Mundell told this newspaperhe is unsure about the idea of reinstating National Service, a programme which meant men aged - had to serve in one of the armed forces for  months.Mr Mundell said: ldquoWe already have a form of National Service emerging with the many thousands of public-spirited people coming forward to volunteer to help with the response to coronavirus.ldquoThe contribution in Tweeddale has been exceptional and that has been the case in many parts of Scotland and across the UK.ldquoMany young people have been doing their bit. We already have an lsquoarmyrsquo of volunteers and they are doing a fantastic job.ldquoIrsquom not sure we need to bring back National Service in the current circumstances. It could end up a bit of a distraction ldquoWe have very professional armed forces, who are currently doing a great deal to help, not all in the public domain."They are achieving a huge amount, particularly on the logistics front and supporting the expanded testing programme.Sir Hews report was commissioned by the Ministry of Defences development, concepts and doctrine centre , a ministry think-tank, in .

title: family-find-121-year-old-copy-borders-newspaper
story: A COUPLE have expressed their amazement at finding a -year-old copy of a local newspaper while renovating a historic Peebles building.Shona Haslam and her husband Marc purchased the old Peebles Courthouse in .But they were staggered when they discovered a perfectly preserved  edition of the Peebles News.Scottish Borders Council leader Mrs Haslam said: ldquoIt is a fantastic piece of local history and will definitely be finding a special place when the building is finally renovated.Justice was delivered from the former sherf court on the High Street for  years before its closure in .The Haslams bought the property three years ago and it will eventually become their family home, as well as holiday accommodation.The family were astonished when they found the old newspaper, costing one half-penny, dated February , .Mrs Haslam told us: ldquoI know DIY is a favourite lockdown activity for many, and in the Courthouse we have our fair share."While we were cleaning out, in one of the many boxes that we found when we moved in, I discovered this absolute gem of a Peebles Newsfrom ."She added: ldquoWhat always amazes me is how many of the names are still recognisable as well-kent within the town. You only need to look at the names of the committee of the March Riders meeting to see so many familiar surnames."The newspapers content included:A notice from the Town Clerk WM Buchan, requesting householders not to put paper in their ash buckets daily.Details of the Peebles Choral Society Annual ConcertAn auction sale of plants and shrubs in James Smithrsquos Auction Rooms at  and  Northgate, PeeblesAdverts for umbrella repairs by Turnbullrsquos John Dougallrsquos watchmaker, jeweller, cycle agent and optician John Greenrsquos winter clothing WM Weatherston  Son, Saddlers and Harness Makers Walter Mitchellrsquos Bootmaker, NorthgateHouses for sale ndash Cottages at Walkershaugh, Damdale, and Wemyss PlaceSports reports from Leithen Rovers, Peebles Rangers, Peebles Rovers, Walkerburn ThistleAn article detailing a public meeting of the Peebles March Riding which was presided over by Provost Ballantyne in the Town HallAn annual meeting of the Peebles Brass Band in the Masonic Hall where Chairman Mr J A Kerr presided over a most ldquomeagre attendance of the public, which he took as a sign that the public had no fault to find with their management

title: teacher-urges-athletes-run-virtual-three-bridges-races
story: DESPITE the annual Three Bridges Races in Peebles being cancelled this year, families are being asked to go the distance for the NHS.Due to coronavirus-related restrictions, the whistle was blown on the mass event which had been due to take place on Sunday.However, Peebles PE teacher Richard Edge has found a way over that hurdle and says people can still take part.He explained: ldquoDue to the current situation and the subsequent cancellation of numerous sporting events, I have no doubt that many of our young athletes will be missing a little bit of competition."I would like to invite anyone to run the equivalent distance of the infamous lsquoThree Bridges Racersquo which is . miles .k.Entry is free but competitors are being invited to make a donation through a fundraising page for the NHS.The Priorsford Primary teacher says the route does not have to cover the bridges.ldquoIn fact I would only suggest running this routevery early in the morning or later in the evening," he said."Itrsquos very important that you adhere to the current social distancing guidelines.ldquoItrsquos quite good fun working out a route, so work together with older family members and create one that suits you."This year, however, there will not be any gold medals being doled out. ldquoThe winner will receive absolutely nothing ndash just the joy of being part of the first virtual Three Bridges," said Mr Edge.Families can also take part in a team event, the teacher explained.ldquoAs we are spending longer with kids, a family run may be fun, Mr Edge said. "A group of three or more people can do a run and finish together. Your family timed run should be titled lsquo bridges virtual family runrsquo."Just as would-be competitors are being asked not to drive to their start lines, they are also being urged to obey social distancing rules when out running.Mr Edge said: ldquoBe considerate to other people by keeping a minimum of m distance at all times when passing. Runs must be completed solo, unless you are running as a family."Entrants are asked to submit their finishing times online before May .Mr Edge said: ldquoSome people will have access to a watch that will be able to time the run and will be linked to something like Strava map my run. If you do not have a watch, use a smart phone with one of the running apps open and record it that way."Once you have recorded your run, you are invited to title it lsquo bridges virtual runrsquo, take a screen shot and email it to: Gwedgerichard@glow.sch.uk, including your name and year of birth.Mr Edge added: ldquoA selfie at the finish of your run would be pretty cool. I will then try and use the information to create final results.If you would like to make a donation to the NHS, visit this website.

title: virus-test-centre-opens-galashiels-key-workers
story: KEY workers in the Borders who are self-isolating can now be tested for coronavirus in Galashiels.A centre at Netherdale car park is open from todayuntil May .The facility, run by the military, will allow key workers who are displaying symptoms to be tested for the virus, with family members also eligiblethey live under the same roof.Scottish Borders Councilsays the site poses no threat to the public, adding that all equipment will be removed at the end of each day.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: "I am delighted that we have managed to work with partners to quickly put in place plans to provide drive-through testing for key workers in the Scottish Borders."Irsquod urge any key worker who is self isolating, either because they themselves have symptoms of COVID- or because a member of their household is, to book tests."Testing is open to four priority groups, with those in Priority Group One already having access to NHS testing facilities.Priority Group Two includes "essential workers in critical national infrastructure fundamental for safety and security, and le-line services" Priority Group Three includes "staff directly involved in delivering other essential services" and Priority Group Four is for "staff involved in volunteering, or in nationally or locally signicant industry important to economic sustainability and growth".Key workers should visit this websiteto book their slot at the centre, which has been set up to support the UK Governments testing programme.

title: holiday-refunds---rights-get-money-back
story: Banks nationwide have blocked "billions of pounds" worth of refunds for holidays cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak.It is estimated that the public is collectively owed about pound billion from travel firms.Forced instead to turn to their banks for help, many customers have now been told they are not eligible for a refund.Heres what you need to know.Why arenrsquot travel firms giving refunds Consumer watchdog Which  recently revealed that  of the UKrsquos largest airlines and travel firms are illegally withholding refunds which should be paid to customers within  days.Instead, most customers have been offered vouchers or credit notes, with many complaining that they have been unable to claim a refund online, or get through to customer services on the phone to ask for their money back.Should I ask my bank for a refund Customers who have been refused a refund by travel firms and paid for their trip using a credit card can claim the money back from their provider under Section  of the Consumer Rights Act.Credit card providers are jointly liable with the retailer or trader for any breach of contract for misrepresentation, providing the value is more than pound and less than pound,.However, Which  has warned that some credit card customers have been told by their provider that theyre not eligible for a refund through the scheme.Others have been informed that their claim wonrsquot be processed until they have tried to claim the cash from the travel firm first, even though this is not a legal requirement.Customers are also able to claim through a process known as chargeback, which allows a transaction to be reversedyou are unable to resolve a dispute, including services not delivered.This covers all card payments and is a process agreed between financial institutions and the relevant card scheme, such as Mastercard and Visa.What are Mastercard and Visarsquos chargeback rights Mastercard said there is a chargeback right where firms have cancelled goods or services, even where this is due to government restrictions, insolvency or other exceptional circumstances.It is also validthe cardholder doesnrsquot wish to accept the firmrsquos offer to rebook or claim a voucher, but the issue should first be attempted to be resolved with the firm.Visarsquos guidance also states that firms should process a refund promptlycustomers decline a credit note or voucher, and cardholders do have a right to complain when goods or services are not provided.However, Visa does make an exception where firms have failed to provide a service due to a government-imposed travel ban, stating that this ldquosupersedes Visa rules on dispute rights.For this reason, Mastercard customers are likely to be more successful when making chargeback claims for coronavirus-related cancellations.If flights are cancelled due to closed borders, customers will still have a dispute right under both Mastercard and Visa, as EU-wide rules around refunds override the government travel ban, according to Which .Which banks will refund under Section  and chargeback Banks have said that they will assess each case inidually when it comes to refunds from firms only offering credit notes or rebooking a cancelled trip.This is what the major banks told Which  about issuing refunds:Where a provider has not met their legal obligations to the customer, Barclays will consider both chargeback and Section  claims, provided the relevant criteria are met.HSBC, including First Directand MS Bank, will allow a chargeback or Section  claim to be made for goods or services not received, but customers are encouraged to contact their airline first.Lloyds Group, including Halaxand Bank of Scotlandsay thata refund is not offered by the travel firm and a customer has proof of this, the bank can pursue a disputed transaction claim under scheme rules.Bankrsquos position is that every chargeback and dispute is dferent, and each claim will need to be assessed on a case-by-case basis with the customer to work out the best solution.Nationwidealso says each case will be looked at on a case-by-case basis because it depends on the type of good services being purchased and what the terms of the agreement are with the merchant.Similarly, RBS, including Natwestand Ulster Bank, said cases would be considered on an inidual basis.If a claim made with the merchant in the first instance is not satisfactory, customers can contact Santanderto raise a claim.,params: .pushWhere the merchant has offered the chance to rebook for free and or provide vouchers and the customer is not satisfied with this then Starling Banksays it would initiate a chargeback.If a merchant is not offering a refund, or are asking customers to contact their card issuers to process a refund, Tesco Bankcustomers can raise a dispute.The Co-operative Banksays thatcustomers tried to resolve the issue with the merchant first but there was no refund or resolution, the bank would look at each case inidually to verya dispute chargeback right existed. If a chargeback right existed but the cardholder accepted a credit voucher, this would not affect the cardholderrsquos original dispute rights. The bank would also not reject a Section  claim outright in these circumstances.If customers are offered a voucher or a chance to rebook, TSBwould typically accept the claims and each case will be considered inidually.If the customer is unhappy with the solution offered by the merchant, Virgin Moneywould consider the terms and conditions. If the alternative arrangements are not covered, a chargeback would normally be successful. Section  claims will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

title: 5g-mast-proposed-galashiels-council-land
story: PLANS for a G mast in Galashiels have been lodged with Scottish Borders Council .The applicationwould see the .-metresteel pole placed on the verge of the townrsquos King Street, on land owned by the council.Residents are now able to submit their views on the proposal, put forward by Harlequin Group on behalf of EE Ltd.Galashielscouncillor Euan Jardine said: "I believe it is important for our local economy that we are on level terms with other towns throughout the country in regards to G provision."It will also have some positive aspects for recreational usage and help to usher in advancements in technology that will change a lot of how we go about our daily lives."Mr Jardine added that he had not been approached by any residents about the application.Meanwhile, his ward colleagueHarry Scott told the Border he was not aware of the plans.Mr Scott said: "I would need to study the application and the circumstances around it before coming to any conclusions."The application, ref   C, can be viewed on the council website.

title: borders-homes-can-book-virtual-visit-auctioneer-bonhams
story: BORDERS residents have the chance to invite a world-famous auctioneer to look round their homes this week.Bonhams is delivering a free valuation service through video conferencing apps.And this week, households in the Borders are under the spotlight, with residents being asked to dig out paintings, jewellery, furniture and collectables.Bonhams Scotland managing director Charles Graham-Campbell said: "Wersquore trying to adapt and do these valuations in a way thatrsquos safe for everybody.Appointments are available from Tuesday until Thursday , am to pm.Items that can be assessed include paintings, silver, jewellery, ceramics, glass, clocks, works of art, furniture, Asian items, and collectables such as whisky.Mr Graham-Campbell, , said: ldquoWersquove always provided valuations where people have sent in photographs but we havenrsquot actually done a Zoom, Teams or WhatsApp virtual meeting ndash a video going round a house looking at objects.ldquoSo this is something new, itrsquos the antique world adapting to the situation we currently find ourselves in. Like other places, we are shut down at the moment."We canrsquot do a lot of work, but wersquore happy to try and help people where we can.Mr Graham-Campbell said it is more useful to see the house via video than to have photographs sent to the company.He said: ldquoWersquore quite used to handling photographs and working from photographs as a profession."It is always best to handle things, and there is always a caveat that the valuation is subject to further research.ldquoBut when we ask people to send in a photograph, they send in a photo of what they think is valuable, and what they think is a family heirloom."But so often when we go to a house, wersquore asked to go and look at a piece of furniture, for example, but actually itrsquos a small Chinese vase, sitting inside a cabinet, thatrsquos the valuable little item and theyrsquoll make more money than all the furniture put together. And they wonrsquot have necessarily known that.Even during the COVID- crisis, valuations continue to be required, Mr Graham-Campbell said.ldquoPeople take over something or inherit it and suddenly need an accurate insurance valuation and we can again have a look round and provide a stopgap valuation, until the times when we can do things in the correct manner, said Mr Graham-Campbell.ldquoThings that are being valued for a business need to be done to comply with their insurance every five years or something."Items need to be valued either for insurance or for probate, or executry purposes."Much of Bonhamsrsquo business is auctioneering, which has also had to be put on hold.Mr Graham-Campbell said: ldquoWith the situation as it is now, there are some people wanting to raise a sum of money and theyrsquove maybe invested in antiques in the past and theyrsquore using that as part of their pension fund.,params: .push"Theyrsquove maybe spent more on buying some paintings than putting into a pension fund and then theyrsquore wanting to realise those assets just to live or give something to their children who are having a hard time and not working at the moment.Scottish auctions normally take place at the Bonhams venue in Queen Street, Edinburgh, and these will also now be taking place online.Mr Graham-Campbell said: ldquoWersquore starting to do virtual auctions ndash wersquove done online auctions in the past, so wersquore quite used to doing them, but wersquore starting to work out how we can do more of them and then wersquore going to do a live auction behind closed doors."Wersquore hopefully going to be able to do that with maybe a live auctioneer and telephone bidders working from home and a clerk at a safe distance away."But the actual venue will be shut to the general public, and the public will be at home bidding away on their computers.ldquoThere are ways that we can work in a safe manner in the near future.To book a virtual valuation appointment, or for more information, email valuations.scotland@bonhams or call Charles Graham-Campbell on

title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: borders-buses-puts-hand-sanitiser-vehicles

title: borders-gp-practices-stay-open-early-may-bank-holiday
story: HEALTH centres and GP practices in the Borders will remain open on Friday, despite the public holiday.The early May bank holiday is taking place on May  to coincide with VE Day.But NHS Borders wants to let people know that they will still be able to contact their health centres and practices over the phone.Patients should not attend in person unless told to do so, according to NHS Borders.Meanwhile, some community pharmacies will also remain open on Friday.For information on your local pharmacys opening hours, you can click here.The early May bank holiday usually takes place on the first Monday of the month.

title: galashiels-postman-wears-superhero-costume-round
story: A GALASHIELS postman has been wearing a superhero costume while delivering parcels.James Morley, , of Melrose, raises a chuckle on his round by donning an Iron Man suit with his high-vis vest.Mr Morley said: "If people smile or laugh because of me, thats all I wanted."The stunt has been particularly popular with older residents, according to Mr Morley.He said: "Older people are at home and havent been able to see their grandchildren and families."A lot of them wanted the photos so they could say that Iron Man delivered their post."Ive had people whove missed me asking me to come back round again so they can get photos and their children can see me through the window."But Mr Morley, based at Galashiels Delivery Office, might not be the only superhero postie in town for much longer.He told the Border : "I may have convinced colleagues to join me. Were trying to organise a day when we can all dress up."Most of my colleagues, when I said I was going to do this, they didnt believe me until I walked into the office."It is unclear whether other members of the Marvel Avengers will join Mr Morley, but some residents are already suggesting he showcase other superheroes, including Spiderman and Batman.For now, however, Mr Morley and his colleagues ndash in costume or not ndash are continuing to provide their key service in abnormal circumstances."Our job has changed drastically," Mr Morley said. "In some respects its easier, leaving parcels at the door for contactless deliveries, but its a bit like Christmas as everyones at home so theyre ordering more as they cant go out."Its like Christmas but with fewer staff, too."Were just trying our best to press on with bringing parcels and letters to people."If you know of any other key workers going above and beyond to improve peoples days during lockdown, get in touch by emailing editorial@bordertelegraph or by messaging our Facebook page at www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: whirlpool-washing-machine-recall-extended-models---full-list
story: An additional  washing machines and tumble dryers haved been recalled by Whirlpool after being deemed to be a fire risk.Heres what you need to doyou have an affected model.What hasWhirlpool said The update comes from the Whirlpool website as ofApril , which states: ldquoAs part of ongoing in-depth checks carried out by Whirlpoolrsquos safety team, we are adding  additional models to the recall.The machines are being recalled because, as Whirlpool explains:ldquoWhen the heating element in the washing machine is activated, in very rare cases a component in the door lock system can overheat, which, depending on product features, can pose a risk of fire.If you have already checked your machine due to previous recalls, you will need to check it again.The recalled washing machines were manufactured under the brands of Hotpoint and Indesit between  and .The full list of recalled modelsThese are the recalled models that have been added to the list of recalled machines by Whirlpool:WMAQB P UKWMAQB P UKWMAQB G UKWMAQB P UKWMAQF P UK.LWMAQF G UKWMAQF P UKWMAQF P UKWMAQG G UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UK.MWMAQG P UK.MWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL A UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UK.MWMAQL G UKWMAQL P UKWMSAQG G UKHow to checkyoursquore affectedIf you think your washing machine is affected by the recall,head to the dedicated Whirlpool recall website-washingmachinerecall.whirlpool.Yoursquoll need to enter your postcode and your model number, and the website will be able to tell youyour model is part of the recall.If it is, yoursquoll then be taken to a new page which asks you to register, which will allow Whirlpool to get in contact with you.Yoursquoll need to fill out your name, email address, phone number and home address. Yoursquoll also need to state where you bought the machine from as well.Alternatively, you can phone   .What happensmy machine is being recalled If your machine is affected by the recall, then you are advised to unplug your appliance and stop using it immediately.If you must continue using it, you should use only a cold water cycle of  degrees celsius or lower.This will stop the washing machinersquos heating element from being activated and therefore poses less of a risk.Whirlpool Vice President, Jeff Noel, said:ldquoWe will still continue to provide a free-of-charge replacement of comparable specication or in-home engineering repair to all affected customers in as safe a way as possible.ldquoWe understand that in the current climate, some customers will have health and safety concerns around our delivery partners or engineers entering their homes to carry out replacements or repairs.ldquoWe continue to follow government guidelines, with strict health and safety processes across our operations, including equipping all our delivery drivers and engineers with personal protective equipment and hand sanitiser.ldquoHowever, we will also offer customers the option of contactless delivery and removal of affected appliances.

title: melrose-shops-praise-volunteers-free-deliveries-start
story: TRADERS in Melrose have joined forces to offer free delivery to customers who are unable to leave their homes.Butcher Martin Baird, , has recruited a raft of volunteer drivers to serve products from his shop and three others.Mr Baird said customer feedback has been ldquogreat, adding: ldquoWe had nearly  deliveries today ndash itrsquos really gone bananas.Other businesses taking part in the scheme are the Country Kitchen Deli, the Premier newsagent and vegetable shop Purple Plum.Mr Baird, whose shop has been on the high street for  years, said at least  people have volunteered to deliver.ldquoI try to give them payment, but they wonrsquot accept it ndash so I just give them a bit of meat, he told the Border .Drop-offs are being made in Galashiels almost every day, said Mr Baird, with some households in Stow, Bowden and Kelso also seeking help.Mr Baird said his business has always been popular, but demand has shot up during the coronavirus lockdown.He said: ldquoIrsquove taken on a couple of youngsters just for this period andthis keeps up, I might have to employ a couple more, because I canrsquot keep working  hours a week.Ready-made meals are proving to be a major hit, Mr Baird said. Big sellers include roast beef, lasagne and sweet and sour dishes.ldquoThe amount of mince Irsquove sold is just incredible. And wersquove got a full-time pie man and hersquos just having to work his socks off, Mr Baird said, adding: ldquoWersquore the lucky ones, being busy ndash I feel for some people.In a joint statement, the four shop owners said they are ldquoincredibly thankful for the help provided by volunteers.Commending their efforts, the statement added: ldquoThey are actively committed to continuing to provide this essential doorstep service to all those who require it.

title: welsh-assembly-begins-life-new-name
story: The devolved parliament of Wales has officially changed its name to Senedd Cymru ndash the Welsh Parliament.The names in Welsh and English refer to the the legislative body formally known as the National Assembly of Wales,  years after devolution began to see law-making and taxation powers moved from London to Cardf.First Minister Mark Drakeford said the new name ndash which is expected to be commonly shortened to ldquothe Senedd ndash would send out a message that it was a ldquofull blown primary law-making institution.The changes are part of a bill which also sees the Seneddrsquos  members renamed Members of the Seneddas opposed to Assembly Members .vw,vw,px, px"Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford during a joint press conference with Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon at Bishop Partridge Hall, Westminster.The bill also lowers the voting age to  for Senedd elections, extends the right to vote to eligible foreign nationals, and changes the law so that most disqualications prohibit a person from taking up a seat in the Senedd though they can still stand for election.Mr Drakeford told the PA news agency: ldquoThe name is catching up with the reality of the institution, because the assembly has been a parliament ndash it has been a Senedd ndash in my view for the last decade since it acquired primary law making powers.ldquoI think itrsquos important to send a message out to people in Wales that an institution which began with very modest powers has over  years developed into a full blown primary lawmaking institution with far deeper powers and wider powers as well.The first minister said the immediate priorities for the Senedd would be continuing to shape the laws governing the coronavirus lockdown and overseeing the work of the Welsh Government, while soon it will scrutinise the Autumn budget.The Covid- outbreak means work to replace signage has had to be suspended, while an event to mark the change will not be held until the lockdown has eased and it is safe for politicians to .But the Seneddrsquos presiding officer Elin Jones will acknowledge the new name with a short statement during the first Plenary meeting as Senedd Cymru on Wednesday afternoon.Secretary of State for Wales Simon Hart said the name change for the institution came at a time ldquowhen its role and close working relationship with the UK Government are more important than ever.He said: ldquoThe coronavirus pandemic is the greatest challenge that politicians in Westminster and Cardf Bay have faced together.Todayrsquos @seneddcypeCommittee meeting was the last formal business of the National Assembly for Wales, before we become Senedd Cymru, the Welsh Parliament tomorrow @seneddwales#Seneddpic gPsKgULTDmdash Senedd CYPEMay , ldquoWhen the emergency is over, we will continue to work constructively with colleagues in the new Senedd Cymru-Welsh Parliament on our shared aims of boosting economic growth, driving inward investment and promoting Wales globally.Group leader of the Welsh Conservatives Paul Davies said he hoped the name change would ldquomake its responsibilities much clearer, emphasising the separate duties between the legislative body and the Welsh Government.Plaid Cymru leader Adam Price hailed the ldquoimportant milestone in our democracy, and called for the Senedd to have even stronger powers over energy, justice, broadcasting and the economy ldquoso that people in Wales have a full and final say on all the big decisions which impact their lives.The National Assembly for Wales was opened in  following the result of a referendum in  which won by just .% of the vote, but it was only given limited law-making powers through the Government of Wales Act .Devolved areas include health, education, economic development, transport, the environment, agriculture and local government..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Welsh Assembly begins le under new name

title: pelosi-pushes-pandemic-aid-package-republicans-exercise-caution
story: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is pressing ahead with the next pandemic aid package as Republicans insist such assistance should be paused.Democrats are expected to propose another round of direct cash aid for anxious Americans, funds for states to prevent layoffs and more money to shore up businesses in the stay-home economy. title: hundreds-meals-head-hardship
story: As well as providing food to children who would usually get free school meals, cooked meals are being delivered to other families in need.A number of items have been donated by local businesses and members of the community, with meals being cooked by volunteers in the Port Seton Centre.Bryan Hickman, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council chair, said: ldquoWersquove been delivering over  things a day to the community ndash itrsquos been a big effort in every part. It is all being done safely.Food items have been donated by a number of local businesses, including Seton Sands Holiday Park, which gave several snack items as well as cereal, fruit and drinks.The event is postponed, also donated money that would have been spent on this yearrsquos event.The local community council, Parent Teacher Association and Chalmers Memorial Church also contributed.Bryan added: ldquoMost of those we have been delivering to have been nominated by other people.ldquoTherersquos about  or  families that receive free school meals in the area and around  OAPs, so itrsquos a title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-delivers-easter-eggs-east-lothian-youngsters
story: Taylor, the current IBF and WBA super lightweight champion, joined forces with the Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes organisation who were delivering the chocolate treats to families in East Lothian.The kind-hearted pugilist, , surprised scores of children in Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton when he and his furry friend knocked on their door to hand over the free eggs.The charity took to social media to thank the undefeated boxing champ and to reveal local police officers also got in on the act with the boxer.Their message read: ldquoA huge thank you to Josh Taylor for helping us deliver Easter Eggs to the children in our community today.ldquoLots of very excited children and it was lovely to see so many smiling faces. We even got stopped by the police and thought we were in trouble but they just wanted a photo with us. Lol.ldquoSorry we could not get to every street, we did our best.One delighted customer said: ldquoA huge thank you for today. My husband died eight weeks ago and I have been struggling so much financially and mentally I contacted your wonderful project to get a chicken dinner box.ldquoI [also] asked for the Easter Bunny to visit as I knew it would be lovely for my kids ndash never did we expect Josh Taylor at the door.ldquoMy kids loved it and I have never seen them so excited or smile like this since their daddy died.ldquoThey spoke about it all day, especially my son who is a huge Josh fan ndash you have no idea the joy you have brought to this house today.Another mum said: ldquoMy two were over the moon with their eggs and a visit from the champ himself.And a delighted grandmother added: ldquoWell done guys ndash my grandson just had a visit and the look on his wee face says it all. Thank you from a grateful gran.The Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes charity provides fresh chicken meals to people who are struggling financially in the East Lothian area.Taylor, from Prestonpans, unied the IBF and WBA super lightweight titles, as well as lting the World Boxing Super Seriesrsquo Muhammad Ali Trophy with victory over Regis Prograis in London last October.

title: couples-diamond-anniversary-party-hold-thanks-virus
story: Robert and Kay Mackie, of North Crescent, celebrated  years of marriage on April .They had originally planned a meal with  close friends and family at the Prestoungrange Gothenburg on April , but the dinner had to be postponed.Robert was born in Edinburgh on November , , and has lived in Prestonpans all his le, attending local primary and high schools.He worked in a garage and then as a miner, working in dferent pits until his retirement in .He is a keen golfer and a member of the Royal Musselburgh Golf Club.Kay was born in Canada on November , , but moved with her family to Carmichael, Lanark, when she was three or four years old.The pair met dancing at the Cavendish club in Edinburgh in May , and were engaged at Christmas the same year.They married a year later at Glencorse Church, near Penicuik.Kay worked in an office until she and Robert started their own family Sheila was born in  and Diana in .The family lived in Cockenzie for seven years before moving to Prestonpans. Robert and Kay have now lived in the same house for  years.Sheila explained why her parents had decided to marry on April .She said: ldquoMy mumrsquos only brother, Michael Robertson, was emigrating back to Canada and she wanted him at the wedding.ldquoThat was the only date they could get before he emigrated he moved back the week after and still lives there now. It was nothing to do with April Foolrsquos Day!The pair have three grandchildren, one great grandson and two step-great granddaughters. Sheilarsquos eldest son, Calum, was born in  and she said the new grandparents were soon taking on babysitting duties.Sheila said: ldquoTheyrsquore really family orientated and helped a lot with bringing the kids up. They would go to their house after school.With celebration plans now on hold, the family instead spent part of the morning waving to the happy couple from afar.Sheila said: ldquoWe went round in the morning and waved in the window. It was nice to see them theyrsquore celebrating so many years married.When asked their secret to a long and happy marriage, Sheila added: ldquoThey said to listen to each other and to not go to bed on an argument.

title: boys-birthday-bagpipe-tunes-bring-smile-kids-faces
story: Sam Johnston, , of Tweedie Place, North Berwick, has been playing lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo on his bagpipes for other young residents in the Walker Homes Glen Ora development.Law Primary School P pupil Sam, who plays for Preston Lodge Pipe Band, is helping children with birthdays celebrate their special day despite lockdown.It started when one mum, Fee Andrews, posted on a neighbourhood Facebook group asking for people to hang out of their windows and sing lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo to her son Brodie.Samrsquos mum Fiona suggested that he could play the bagpipes and, after playing for four-year-old Brodie, who described the experience as ldquogood, Sam has been inundated with requests.In keeping with social distancing guidelines, Sam plays the tune by his front door, with neighbours welcome to stand on the pavement and sing along.Fiona said: ldquoHe has been practising in the garden every day, and is doing his lessons online.ldquoHersquos doing something good for his community ndash giving his pipes a blow and doing something nice forthe kids that are stuck inside.ldquoI am really proud of him. He doesnrsquot like standing up in front of people so it is good he is putting himself out there when things are tough.ldquoWe are a family of pipers ndash Samrsquos papa and two of his uncles are pipers.ldquoItrsquos a family tradition to play the pipes on someonersquos birthday when the cake comes in. Itrsquos so nice that he is sharing that tradition with the kids.ldquoOne girl was too shy to stand at the door so Sam stood in the back garden and piped for her ndash she could hear it from her house.ldquoItrsquos something a bit fun to do and helps brighten their day. Itrsquos so uplting and makes people feel better we just thought it would be a wee bit of fun.ldquoSamrsquos birthday was April  so he knows how it feels.ldquoI donrsquot think he understands how big it is hersquos making people smile.Fiona added: ldquoIrsquove met more neighbours in the past few weeks than the past year of living here.Fee said: ldquoItrsquos a really lovely thing that he is doing and hersquos such a nice boy as well.ldquoBrodie kept saying, lsquoMum is that for me, is that for mersquo ldquoItrsquos brought the community closer together. When it was Samrsquos birthday, a few people came out to sing for him.At the beginning of the month Sam also played for Josie Wheatley, who was celebrating her seventh birthday. With her birthday party cancelled, and unable to celebrate with friends and family, Josie was delighted to have Sam play his bagpipes for her.Josiersquos mum Emma said: ldquoJosie said she felt happy and amazing after being piped for and being sung to by all the neighbours. It really made her feel special. She phoned all of her friends and family to tell them about her special day. It really made her feel like she had a great birthday.ldquoWhen she heard it [the music] she was so over the moon.ldquoDuring such worrying times, Sam brings a smile to the childrenrsquos faces.ldquoI just think someone who is , to put themselves out there and to make these young people feel so special is such an amazing thing to do.ldquoItrsquos so nice to see a young lad use his skills to bring happiness to children on their birthdays.

title: learning-lockdown-can-tough-council-admits
story: Lesley Brown, East Lothianrsquos chief education officer, encouraged such families, while agreeing it was not easy.She said: ldquoWith this being a dficult time, itrsquos important to recognise that we do not expect children and young people to always follow a typical school day, especially when parents are sometimes having to juggle other tasks such as looking after others or working from home.ldquoLearning can be carried out in a flexible way to suit a child familyrsquos inidual circumstances and,you have any questions about this or the best approach to take, please do not hesitate to contact your school.ldquoOur school staff will continue to embrace a flexible creative approach to learning and teaching, where possible maximising the use of digital technology to support learning for children who are being cared for at home.ldquoTeachers will continue posting [online] learning assignment tasks for children, including active learning opportunities which they can undertake with their families.ldquoAnyone who doesnrsquot have a phone or internet access should let their school know. They will ensure you have the ability to stay in contact with school staff and receive information and support in continuing childrenrsquos learning.The Young Scot website has useful advice and information, while BBC Bitesize is a helpful learning support resource for school-aged young people.Judith Tait, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for childrenrsquos services, added: ldquoWe recognise it is a very dficult time for families and that our children will be missing their friends and the daily interaction they get from school and clubs.ldquoWe also understand the challenges of keeping children and young people engaged in learning without the structure of the school day.ldquoWhile home will be the safest place for most young people, we realise this is not necessarily the case for everyone.ldquoThatrsquos why we are highlighting a number of people or organisations who can helpanyone feels worried, upset or unsafe ndash either for themselves or, indeed, someone .The councilrsquos advice in such circumstances is: l If possible, speak to an adult you know and trust who can listen and take action to helpl Although schools are closed, staff are still available to talk to. Call    or   .l If you or someone you know is in immediate danger call the police on .l With schools being closed, children will be spending more time online and must be protected from cyberbullying and online grooming. title: heavy-sound-bit-put-food-table
story: Heavy Sound, based in Tranent, has joined forces with other groups, including the townrsquos Fundamental Foods, to help get food to those in need.The social enterprise is also working alongside the Edinburgh International Conference Centre .With conferences and events at the city venue cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak, Heavy Sound is partnering them to distribute food from the EICCrsquos kitchens to vulnerable communities in and around Edinburgh.Jordan Butler, Heavy Sound CEO, said: ldquoAlthough we canrsquot deliver our usual programmes at schools, we have resources and staff who are willing to support in whatever way they can.ldquoWe were already dealing with food poverty and isolation in our communities, something that has only been exacerbated by the pandemic.ldquoLow income, mental health, complex trauma and unemployment are factors at play, and the only silver lining has been around how people and businesses like the EICC are pulling together and collaborating in new ways to make a dference.Heavy Sound usually uses music, arts and sport to work with young people from a iety of backgrounds.Last year, the social enterprise revealed plans to work alongside the Scottish Prison Serviceand Police Scotlandrsquos Violence Reduction Unit to transform an old bus into a portable community service, complete with music production equipment, a food prep kitchen and a small hairdressing space.EICC is also working alongside FareShare during the global pandemic to help vulnerable members of the community.Marshall Dallas, EICC CEO, added: ldquoWith a signicant amount of food in our kitchens that wersquore unable to use for events, the natural thing to do was to find ways of getting it to the people who need it most just now.ldquoThe work being done by FareShare across the UK and Heavy Sound in Edinburgh and East Lothian is quite staggering their teams are working tirelessly to get food to so many communities and itrsquos a real privilege to play a part in that.

title: sisters-transform-bar-musselburghs-friendliest-pub
story: Rebecca and Victoria Fowler took over The Sportsman Bar in May last year, with a view to transforming the High Street premises.The venue has signed up to Best Bar None Scotland and Rebecca, of Tranent, felt it had made a massive dference in turning the business around.She said: ldquoHaving previously worked in The Sportsman, we knew what we were taking on but also knew it was something we could make work.ldquoThe pub had a bit of a reputation. We wanted to turn it into a safe place for people to come and enjoy a night out with a bit of banter thrown in: lsquoMusselburghrsquos friendliest pub.rsquo But we knew this wouldnrsquot happen overnight.Best Bar None Scotland aims to ensure everyone can enjoy a safe night out.The national scheme, which works through a partnership between local authorities, the Scottish Government, Police Scotland, Scottish Fire and Rescue Service and other organisations, works to reduce crime, reward excellence, and raise standards of alcohol licensed premises.Rebecca added: ldquoLicensing recommended title: extension-planned-school-prestonpans
story: East Lothian Council wants to add two classrooms to the east side of St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School, in Prestonpans, as more housing being built in the town is expected to increase the title: inspired-irene-knits-charity
story: Irene, who lives in Haddington, has spent her time in lockdown knitting twiddle muffs and aims to produce  to donate to AlzheimerScotland.The colourful muffs provide people with restless hands a distraction and can be a comfort and distraction for some.Irene, , first began producing them six months ago and has used her time at home to challenge herself with her new target.And she has launched a JustGiving page for people to support her efforts and donate to AlzheimerScotland at the same time.She said: "Like so many elderly and vulnerable people, Irsquove found the recentCoronavirus lockdown situation dficult to adjust to in numerous ways."Luckily for me, whilst nowadays Irsquom a bitunsteady on my feet, Irsquom still very keen and pretty capable of doing all sortsof crafts and so have been filling the many hours, days and weeks of socialisolation by knitting twiddle muffs."There are actually several advantages to knitting twiddle muffs. Of course, thefirst and most important benefit is to the recipients ... people with dementiaoften have restless hands and like to have something to keep their handsoccupied."A twiddle muff provides awonderful source of visual, tactile and sensory stimulation, and keeps handssnug and warm at the same time."But Irsquovefound there are also benefits for me too ndash not only is knitting keeping mephysically and mentally occupied, itrsquos also making a great dent in my enormousstock of gorgeous textured and coloured wool that Irsquove been buying and hoardingfor years ... one of my guilty pleasures!"So far Irene, who lives in Monk Muir Park, has doubled her target of pound donations on her JustGiving page which stands at pound,.She said: "WatchingCaptain Tomrsquos recent endeavours to raise such an awesome amount for the NHS hasbeen an inspiration to us all."Irene is asking everyone to support her as she carries on knitting by donating to the charity.She said: "Irsquom now delighted to be donating all the twiddle muffs Irsquom knitting toAlzheimer Scotland for distribution to those in need and Irsquove set myself atarget of knitting a total of muffs."To help motivate me Irsquom hoping that all you generous people mighthelp me raise funds for Alzheimer Scotland, which is Scotlandrsquos nationaldementia charity, whose aim is to make sure that nobody faces dementiaalone."They provide support andinformation to people with dementia, their carers and families, includingproviding a  hour freephone Dementia Helpline."Alzheimer Scotland campaigns for the rightsof people with dementia and funds vital dementia research. Please donate what you can toinspire me to keep these knitting needles clacking."To donate go to bit.ly aCOrO

title: greggs-reveal-plan-reopen-stores-across-country
story: The Newcastle-based bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.The full details of how the trial will operate have not been released.Due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday night : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonalds in talks to reopen storesIt comes after McDonalds said they were in talks about opening its , restaurants across the UK, according to reports.The burger chain could open for drive-thru and delivery orders as early as mid-May, the Irish Farmers Journal said.A spokesperson for McDonalds said: "Of course we are thinking about re-opening and having those conversations ndash but its unclear when that will be."

story: As of yesterday - heres what we know so far.GreggsGreggshaveconfirmed it islooking to reopen with a number of stores expected to reopen their doorsasearly as next week.The bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.Although the full details of how the trial will operate have not been released, it is believed a number ofNewcastlestores will be among the first to welcome customers back.But due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday, April : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonaldsNo confirmed date has been revealed as to when McDonalds will , but work is going on behind the scenes to prepare for a small-but-steadyacross the country.Paul Pomroy, McDonaldrsquos CEO UK and Ireland said on Tuesday, April :"In March, we took the decision to temporarily close our restaurants in the UK and Ireland for the safety of our people and customers. title: royal-mail-stop-saturday-letter-deliveries-due-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It said it will continue to provide its letter delivery service from Monday to Friday as normal and said customers ldquoshould continue to post both letters and parcels as usual on Saturday.Royal Mail will continue to collect all mail from businesses, post offices and post boxes, it said.When will Saturday deliveries temporarily stop The will be halted from this weekend .What have Royal Mail said Shane OrsquoRiordain, managing director of marketing, regulation and corporate affairs at Royal Mail, said: ldquoOur postmen and postwomen are working very hard across the UK in challenging conditions.ldquoAs we said at the start of the coronavirus crisis, there will be some disruption to services.ldquoWe understand the importance of the postal service in keeping the UK connected at this time.ldquoWe have also listened to our hard-working colleagues who have asked us to ease the additional burden on thempossible. As a result, we are making some temporary changes to postal services.Royal Mail said it has been in dialogue with the Government and regulator Ofcom throughout the crisis and will keep the temporary change to postal arrangements under review.Reaction to the moveThe decision was criticised by the Communication Workersrsquo Union , which represents postal workers.A CWU spokesman said: ldquoWe will be seeking urgent discussions with the Government on this issue.ldquoThe reduction of the Universal Service Obligation was a key factor in our live national strike ballot.ldquoThe last thing we want to do is call strike action at this point but we will not sit back and see our membersrsquo jobs put at threat and the service to the public worsened.Last month the union called for householdsrsquo deliveries to be cut to three days a week due to coronavirus.

title: teachers-well-placed-assess-students-grades
story: The Scottish Qualications Authorityhas revealed how it aims to determine the  exam results for students due to sit them, following the suspension of normal examinations due to Covid-.And Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for education, said schools were prepared to provide the evidence needed and review the results using their professional judgement.She said: ldquoWe know that the closure of schools and the cancellation of exams has caused anxiety and uncertainty for our pupils and their families. Irsquom pleased that the SQA has now confirmed its approach, and I am especially pleased to see recognition that teachers and schools are best-placed to provide a judgement on pupilsrsquo achievements.ldquoOur schools regularly monitor and track pupilsrsquo progress throughout the academic year as part of our approaches to ensuring high-quality learning, teaching and assessment. Teachersrsquo professional judgement is at the heart of our approach in Scotland and our teachers are very well placed to provide the information required by SQA.ldquoWe are working with our headteachers and school teams to make sure that our approach across East Lothian is consistent, rigorous and accurately reflects pupilsrsquo achievements. Our teachers will estimate grades using all evidence available to them, with support from their subject faculties, wider school teams and from our central education team.The SQA says its approach to awarding grades is based on safe and secure certication following public health advice and maintaining the integrity and credibility of the qualications system.Schools and colleges will be asked to provide the SQA with estimates on pupilsrsquo achievements, grades, bands and rank based on their performance so far in subject activities.This will provide an overall judgement from those the SQA describes as ldquobest placed to do so, with submissions due by May .The SQA will then check and validate the estimates it receives and look at prior assessments undertaken by pupilsthey are available ndash for example, Higher results for an Advanced Higher pupil.The schoolsrsquo previous history in estimating attainment will be considered and SQA will hold Awarding Meetings with its subject experts.Results will be delivered to learners by August  and students are encouraged to register for MySQA to receive their results by text and or email.The appeals process will remain free for schools and colleges so they can advocate on their pupilsrsquo behalfthe results do not reflect the candidatersquos achievements.The SQA has an exams QA for parents and pupils on its website, www.sqa.org.uk

title: pubs-may-limit-drinkers-three-pints-lockdown-lifted
story: Heres what you need to know.What social distancing rules could pubs face When pubs reopen for business, patrons could be limited to three drinks each before being asked to head home, in order to free up space for others to visit, a government advisor has suggested.The strict rules would also include maintaining a social distance of two metres while inside, with landlords able to issue fines to those who flout the rules.The terms are outlined in a plan by economist and government advisor, Professor Eyal Winter, who said social distancing is the key to coming out of lockdown. He also argued that the public need to know what the government has planned in terms of a lockdown exit strategy.Speaking to , he said: ldquoPeople are starving for pubs. They are an important part of British culture.ldquoOne of the most important things is to have a programme, to say, lsquoIn two weeks we will do such and such.rsquoldquoYou need to make the rules crystal clear, and to explain to the public the rationale behind each one of them.When are pubs likely to reopen Professor Winter estimated that it will take ldquoa lot of time to move back to how le was in January , but was certain that the country ldquowill get there.The Mail Online has reported that a possible exit plan could see the UK come out of lockdown in phases. The public would allegedly be allowed back into outdoor spaces first, with pubs being the last to open, as the lockdown was lted.Cabinet Office minister, Michael Gove, confirmed that areas of hospitality will be among the last to see restrictions lted.When asked whether pubs would open ldquobefore winter, Mr Gove told Sky News: ldquoThe other inference that I draw from your question, which is that areas of hospitality will be among the last to exit the lockdown - yes, that is true.What about cinemas and theatres Professor Winter has also been advising ministers on how to go about lting lockdown, and said cinemas and theatres could also reopen, but must have half empty auditoriums.Every other seat would have to be unoccupied, but he said venues could make up for the loss of money by raising ticket prices.

title: neighbours-join-forces-ensure-memorable-80th-birthday
story: James Walker, known as Jim, lives on St Margarets Road with we Valerie and celebrated his big day on Monday.Initial plans were for his daughter Morag to travel from Ireland, where she currently stays with her partner and family, and his two sons Alastair and Graeme to visit from Staffordshire and Edinburgh respectively.However, the coronavirus lockdown changed this, and meant that his family were not able to be by his side.Morag contacted Jim and Valrsquos lsquolockdown street linkrsquo for the area ndash put in place by the townrsquos resilience team ndash to askanyone could make a cake for her dadrsquos birthday.Morag said: ldquoI knew the street link lady is an active member of the community so would knowanyone was able to help.The plan snowballed from a kind neighbour making a chocolate cake to other neighbours gathering in front of Jim and Valeriersquos house to sing a socially distanced lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo.When he heard his doorbell ring, Jim was amazed to find the chocolate cake at the front door.Neighbours from nearby Marmion Road and St Margarets Road struck up a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo, while Jim waved from the doorstep.He then walked to the pavement to thank everyone.ldquoItrsquos a lovely day for us to eat cake and have a cup of tea in the garden, said we Valerie.Morag said: ldquoMy dad was a bit taken aback but really appreciated the surprise. title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: volunteers-dishing-hundreds-hot-meals
story: The centre is working with Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council on the initiative, with staff at the centre cooking the meals.More than  volunteers at the local resilience group are helping with packing and deliveries.As many as  families are receiving hot meals or food donations, with deliveries made every day. It is also supporting the work of the local school hub by providing children who would usually receive free school meals with breakfast and lunch packs.In the past week,  breakfast packs and  school meals have been issued. They are delivered on a Monday with supplies given to last a week. In recent weeks, the need for the service has gone up. It operates six days a week, with a double service on a Saturday to ensure a full weekrsquos coverage.Bryan Hickman, chairman of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, estimated that  volunteer hours were given to the service every week.He said: ldquoPeople are really grateful for it.ldquoWe might continue running it should the need still be there [after lockdown].
